{{smaller|({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=01|day1=17|year1=2011|month2=04|day2=08|year2=2011}})}}}} | status = '''Ended''' | time = | timezone = | goals = {{longitem|{{hlist |Salary increases |Lower living costs |Jobs |Less corruption{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/28/apworld/20110228155141&sec=apworld |title=Oman protesters stage third day of unrest |work=The Star |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2012 |location=Muscat |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716161722/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F2%2F28%2Fapworld%2F20110228155141&sec=apworld |archive-date=16 July 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}}}}} | methods = {{hlist |[[Demonstration (people)|Demonstration]]s |[[Riot]]s |[[Sit-in]]s}} | injuries = 20[https://montrealgazette.com/news/Protests+escalate+across+region/4363409/story.html Protests escalate across region] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301103757/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Protests%2Bescalate%2Bacross%2Bregion/4363409/story.html |date=1 March 2011 }}, ''The Gazette'' (Montreal), 1 March 2011. Retrieved 2011-03-28. | fatalities = 2–6[http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Oman-Six-killed-in-Sundays-pro-democracy-protests_311735597579.html Oman: 'Six killed' in Sunday's pro-democracy protests], Adnkronos Security, 28 February 2011. Retrieved 2012-01-15. }} {{History of Oman}} The '''2011 Omani protests''' were a series of protests in the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Persian Gulf]] country of [[Oman]] that occurred as part of the [[revolutionary wave]] popularly known as the "[[Arab Spring]]".[http://www.brecorder.com/world/global-business-a-economy/19759-oman-budget-gap-rises-to-658mn-in-q1-spending-up.html Oman budget gap rises to $658mn in Q1, spending up]. ''Business Recorder''. (10 July 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. The protesters demanded salary increases, lower living costs, the creation of more jobs and a reduction in corruption. Protests in [[Sohar]], Oman's fifth-largest city, centered on the [[Globe Roundabout]].[http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/photos/2011/03/02/globe_roundabout_sohar_oman Globe Roundabout – Sohar, Oman | The Middle East Channel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711015914/http://mideast.foreignpolicy.com/photos/2011/03/02/globe_roundabout_sohar_oman |date=11 July 2011 }}. Mideast.foreignpolicy.com. Retrieved 2011-03-28. The [[Qaboos of Oman|Sultan]]'s responses included the dismissal of a third of the governing cabinet.http://www.khaleejtimes.com/displayarticle.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/March/middleeast_March140.xml§ion=middleeast&col= == Issues == Protesters demanded salary increases and lower costs of living. On 20 February 2011, protesters welcomed a move by the government to increase the [[minimum wage]].Al Jazeera. Headlines. The wage increase targets Omani workers in the private sector. Public sector Omani employees have received wage increases in the past, but the private sector was so far overlooked. The [[Government of Oman]] raised minimum wages for an estimated 150,000 private sector employees to $520 from $364 a month.{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110226-oman-boosts-student-benefits |title=Oman boosts student benefits |work=France24 |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2012 |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325131205/http://www.france24.com/en/20110226-oman-boosts-student-benefits |archive-date=25 March 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} As protests continued in Sohar the demands were still jobs and political reforms. The protesters also want more jobs, [[freedom of expression]], less government control over the media, political reforms, better living conditions, an abolition of taxes and the trial of all ministers. Protesters in Muscat also demanded cabinet ministers not serve more than four years.{{cite news|last=Al |first=Saleh |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-oman-protests-idUSTRE71I0V920110219 |title=Oman protesters call for political reform, pay rise |agency=Reuters |date=19 February 2011|accessdate=1 March 2011}} In several other protests, Omanis furthered their demands by calling for a reduction of foreign workers in order to provide more jobs for Omani citizens by private companies.{{cite web|title=Pay raise ends walkout by workers at 300 firms in industrial park in Oman|author=Saleh al Shaibany|date=24 March 2011|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/pay-raise-ends-walkout-by-workers-at-300-firms-in-industrial-park-in-oman|work=The National}} ==Anti-government protests== ===Muscat protests=== About 200 protesters marched on 17 January demanding salary increases and lower costs of living. The protest surprised international observers, who have viewed Oman as a "politically stable and sleepy country."{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/oman-protestors-call-for-fight-against-corruption--374524.html |title=Oman protestors call for fight against corruption – Culture & Society |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date=18 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110222074905/http://www.arabianbusiness.com/oman-protestors-call-for-fight-against-corruption--374524.html| archivedate= 22 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} Renewed protests termed as the ''Green March'',{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=41806&rand=uVGjVlZjQUKJ2MN73tEvK9Y92v |title=Public petition: People awaiting response |author=Fahad Al Ghadani |work=Times of Oman |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717060358/http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=41806&rand=uVGjVlZjQUKJ2MN73tEvK9Y92v |archive-date=17 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} occurred on 18 February, inspired by the serious unrest in fellow Gulf state Bahrain. 350 people marched, demanding an end to corruption and better distribution of oil revenue.{{cite web|last=Spinner |first=Jackie |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2285656/ |title=Middle East protests: Oman's peaceful anti-corruption march |work=Slate |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}} The protesters also carried signs with slogans of support for the Sultan.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/02/19/Oman-protests-peaceful-so-far/UPI-96551298131400/ |title=Oman protests peaceful so far |agency=United Press International|accessdate=19 February 2011}} Police did not intervene in the gathering, the petition calling for the reforms will be handed to Oman's Sultan Qaboos.{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110219/162677613.html |title=Hundreds stage peaceful march in Oman demanding reforms |agency=RIA Novosti |date=3 January 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} On 1 March, about 50 protesters held a [[sit-in]] as well outside the [[Consultative Assembly of Oman|Consultative Assembly]] to demand political reform and an end to corruption.{{cite news|last=Abouzeid |first=Rania |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2057061,00.html?xid=rss-mostpopular |title=Oman: Greetings from the Mideast's Relaxed Revolution |work=Time |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}{{cite news|first=Sunil K. |last=Vaidya |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/peaceful-protests-in-oman-gather-steam-as-more-join-1.771606 |title=Peaceful protests in Oman gather steam as more join |work=[[Gulf News]] |date=4 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} The group later grew to over 400 people.{{cite web|author=Rejimon K. |url=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20110301074616 |title=Demonstrators rally at Majlis Al Shura |publisher=Zawya |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Protesters also continued to demand the Consultative Assembly be turned into a "real parliament." The protests were reported to be "peaceful, well-organised and very disciplined." Tents had been set up with separate accommodations for men and women. Placards with protest slogans had also been translated into English, French and German for the international media. On 2 April, dozens of protesters staged a sit-in in Muscat, outside the chief prosecutor's office, to demand probes into alleged state abuses after clashes with security forces a day earlier. ===Sohar protests=== On 26 February, nearly 500 protesters gathered around a shopping mall in the industrial city of [[Sohar]], 230 kilometres from the capital [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122620711831600.html |title=Oman shuffles cabinet amid protests – Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=1 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110228142654/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122620711831600.html| archivedate= 28 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} The protesters stopped traffic and shoppers around the mall premises. The shops in the area including the mall remained closed on 27 February as well.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/sit-in-in-sohar-town-forces-hypermarkets-to-close-down-1.768284 |title=Sit-in in Sohar town forces hypermarkets to close down |work=Gulf News |accessdate=1 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110301153753/http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/sit-in-in-sohar-town-forces-hypermarkets-to-close-down-1.768284| archivedate= 1 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 27 February, protesters returned in Sohar for a second day, hurling stones at security forces who had cordoned them off.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/27/oman-protests-idUSLDE71Q04I20110227|title=Oman police clash with stone-throwing protesters|agency=Reuters|accessdate=27 February 2011|date=27 February 2011}} The [[Royal Oman Police]] eventually used tear gas and rubber bullets to contain and disperse the protesters. According to witnesses, two protesters were killed.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gh9egWT30AUKwD6gzNoIxvkoqFMg?docId=6083540 |title=The Canadian Press: Omani protesters stage third day of anti-government unrest, latest in Gulf region |publisher=Google |accessdate=1 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011227112850852905.html |title=Deaths in Oman protests – Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |accessdate=1 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110228234440/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011227112850852905.html| archivedate= 28 February 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12590588 |title=Oman clashes: Two killed during protests in Gulf state |publisher=BBC |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110228081115/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12590588| archivedate= 28 February 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 28 February, protesters looted and burned a hypermarket in Sohar.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110303/jsp/nation/story_13661334.jsp |title=Jitters over attack on Indian mall in Oman |work=The Telegraph |location=Calcutta |date=1 March 1999 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} The demonstrators also blocked the entrance to Sohar port, where 160,000 barrels of oil derived products are exported.{{cite web|url=http://www.rttnews.com/Content/GeneralNews.aspx?Id=1563846&SM=1 |title=Oman's Second-Largest Port Blocked By Protesters |publisher=Rttnews.com |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} On 1 March protests continued for a fourth day as crowds in Sohar congregated at the Globe Roundabout. Eventually, the [[Royal Army of Oman|Omani army]], backed by tanks, peacefully dispersed protesters blocking the Sohar port and cleared them from the main coastal highway linking Muscat to Sohar.{{cite web|url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/101712 |title=Tanks roll into Sohar |publisher=Morning Star |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=44659 |title=ميدل ايست أونلاين: |publisher=Middle East Online |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/03/01/army-disperses-protesters-in-oman/ |title=Army disperses protesters in Oman |publisher=Euronews.net |accessdate=6 March 2011}} The troops later pulled back, though five armoured vehicles continued to watch the square.{{cite web |url=http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=79014 |title=Oman forces disperse protesters |work=Pakistan Observer |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310000851/http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=79014 |archive-date=10 March 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The Globe Roundabout had been the site of up to 2,000 demonstrators over the past three days.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131101527815578.html |title=Fresh protests break out in Oman |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110305103424/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131101527815578.html| archivedate= 5 March 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/World/Story/A1Story20110301-265967.html |title=Oman forces disperse protesters peacefully |publisher=AsiaOne |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=2011-03-06}} After reports of multiple deaths, the minister of health of Oman claimed only one person had been killed and 20 wounded.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/01/3151369.htm One dead as protests spread to Oman – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)]. Australian Broadcasting Corporation. (1 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. A ''Facebook'' entitled "March 2 Uprising for Dignity and Freedom" called for further protests in all parts of Oman, beginning on 2 March, and it attracted more than 2,300 users. However, protests only occurred at the Globe Roundabout in Sohar with a smaller crowd of 50 protesters who blockaded the area.{{cite news|last=Mcdowall |first=Angus |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703409904576174571884664378 |title=Protests in Oman Sputter |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} Some people had organised community policing groups to prevent more damage.{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofoman.com/echoice.asp?detail=41362 |title=Sultanate’s security forces unearth UAE spy network |work=Times of Oman |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717060353/http://www.timesofoman.com/echoice.asp?detail=41362# |archive-date=17 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/heavily-armed-military-vehicles-guard-sohar-1.769763 |title=Heavily-armed military vehicles guard Sohar |work=Gulf News |accessdate=6 March 2011}} The army also issued a red alert to vacate the area or threatened action.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/oman-sounds-red-alert-protesters-given-evening-deadline-1.770510 |title=Oman sounds red alert; protesters given evening deadline |work=Gulf News |date=2 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}} The 'Sohar Citizen Committee' as it is called has started giving out numbers of its core members to people who can call upon it in case of an emergency or riots attack. On 30 March, The [[Director of Public Prosecutions]] issued a statement saying that complaints were filed by some citizens about acts of rioting, vandalism and breach of public order, destruction of public and private properties, obstructing business transactions and hindering easy movement of people on the streets. Based on these complaints, he gave orders to arrest and clear all the protesters from the Globe Roundabout. The Omani army then stormed the Globe Roundabout clearing blockades and arresting a number of the protesters.[http://www.eurasiareview.com/oman-soldiers-use-force-to-end-one-month-sit-in-29032011/ Oman: Soldiers Use Force To End One Month Sit-In] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605164136/http://www.eurasiareview.com/oman-soldiers-use-force-to-end-one-month-sit-in-29032011/ |date=5 June 2011 }}. Eurasiareview.com (29 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jCx0tMQLB9ylW1Ng9XB3MDM00ggg?docId=CNG.34a222e35c6a2e98d03744cee3b43b05.621 AFP: Omani army ends pro-reform sit-in]. Google, (28 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15.[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/March/middleeast_March485.xml§ion=middleeast Oman’s Public Prosecution orders arrest of protesters]. ''Khaleej Times'', (30 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15.[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/03/29/Oman-forces-crack-down-on-protesters/UPI-89971301402206/ Oman forces crack down on protesters]. United Press International. Retrieved 2012-01-15.{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFLDE72S0LO20110329?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 | agency=Reuters | title=Oman army clears roadblocks in Sohar pay protest | date=29 March 2011}} On 1 April, following Friday prayers, hundreds of protesters took to streets demanding the release of people detained in the Public Prosecution crackdowns.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gHKIGxf2JZ3o5w-LiUjdo0NE-Zhw?docId=6432720] {{Dead link|date=May 2011}} The military has also stationed units around government offices and other key buildings in the city.{{cite news |title=Oman protests resume |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/20114213219368983.html |date=2 April 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405190130/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/20114213219368983.html| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} At least one person was reported to have been killed in clashes between police and demonstrators[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j1t6UcsUhhalNFSFPviQqiy3pxng?docId=CNG.1fd1c4853d22c9c6fd2476a783525b0d.6e1 AFP: Police shoot one dead in Oman protest: witnesses]. Google. (1 April 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. The Public Prosecutor said that the army responded to the protests which had initially started off as a demonstration demanding the release of over 100 protesters detained by authorities three days before[http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Stories-Files/1-dead-6-injured-as-peace-march-turns-violent-in-Sohar/%28language%29/eng-GB 1 dead, 6 injured as peace march turns violent in Sohar – Oman News]. ''Muscat Daily''. Retrieved 2012-01-15. but he alleged that later involved knives and stones amidst violence that led to the arrests of 50–60 of the demonstrators.{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE7310T320110402 | agency=Reuters | title=Oman detained up to 60 during clashes – witnesses | date=2 April 2011}} Six others were also badly injured in the incident which had initially started off as a peaceful demonstration demanding the release of over 100 protesters detained by authorities three days before. On 8 April, the Public Prosecutor's office release details and photographs of those who had been arrested.[http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Stories-Files/Dragon-Gang-head-arrested-in-Sohar/%28language%29/eng-GB ‘Dragon Gang’ head arrested in Sohar – Oman News]. ''Muscat Daily''. Retrieved 2012-01-15. The same day, though rumours had abounded that a large number of protesters, including women and children, would take to the streets of Sohar after Friday prayers, there were no reports of protests in the local media after the Omani Army took control of the city setting-up multiple checkpoints and making arrests of protest leaders.[http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Stories-Files/Sohar-peaceful-under-heavy-security-cover/%28language%29/eng-GB Sohar peaceful under heavy security cover – Oman News]. ''Muscat Daily''. Retrieved 2012-01-15. ===Other protests=== On 5 March, protests in the country have spread to [[Haima, Oman|Haima]], a key oil region about {{convert|500|km|abbr=on}} southwest of the capital Muscat, with oil workers staging a sit-in and calling for more government investment in the area. There were also protests in [[Ibri]] during the month.[http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Stories-Files/Ministry-of-Manpower-shut-down-forcibly-in-Sohar/%28language%29/eng-GB Ministry of Manpower shut down forcibly in Sohar – Oman News]. ''Muscat Daily''. (27 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. On 6 May, protesters returned to the streets in [[Salalah]] after Friday prayers calling for democratic reform and an end to corruption.[http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/hundreds-call-for-reform-end-to-graft-in-oman Hundreds call for reform, end to graft in Oman – TrustLaw] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406120107/http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/hundreds-call-for-reform-end-to-graft-in-oman |date=6 April 2012 }}. Trust.org (6 May 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. The activists and protesters have reiterated their demands for the sacked ministers to be investigated. This was the fourth consecutive Friday to be marked by protests in Salalah.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} Police broke up a protest camp in Salalah on 12 May, arresting possibly over 100 demonstrators. Several dozen more protesters were attacked by baton-wielding [[gendarmerie|gendarmes]] and arrested the next day and early into the morning of 14 May while they were demanding jobs and higher pay.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/14/us-oman-protests-idUSTRE74D0IN20110514 Omani forces arrest protesters after clashes]. Reuters. 14 May 2011 The ''[[Muscat Daily]]'' reported that protesters clashed with the army in Salalah's central Al Nahda Street following the first wave of arrests. The army then fired into the air and also used tear gas to disperse the stone-throwing crowds.{{cite web|url=http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Stories-Files/Operation-Salalah-army-arrests-protesters/%28language%29/eng-GB|title=Operation Salalah: Omani Army arrests Salalah protesters|work=Muscat Daily|accessdate=17 May 2011}} There were also peaceful protests in various colleges in Oman demanding the reducing of pass grades in some colleges. It had affected the classes in those colleges.[http://sinaw.org/vb/showthread.php?p=212814 منتديات سناو] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827075419/http://sinaw.org/vb/showthread.php?p=212814 |date=27 August 2011 }}. Sinaw.org. Retrieved 2012-01-15. ==Pro-government rallies== On 1 March a rally was organised in Muscat to show support for the Sultan and his government. There were accusations that the government itself organised the rally, though at least some support was a "part genuine outpouring of affection for the sultan." However, multiple [[Short Message Service|sms]] were sent from the state-owned [[Omantel]] network during the nights preceding the protests, urging loyalists to attend.{{cite news|last=Fuller |first=Thomas |title=Rallies in Oman Steer Clear of Criticism of Its Leader |work=The New York Times |page=8 |date=2 March 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/world/middleeast/02oman.html}} There were also continuous reports, mostly from Twitter, that supporters of the government drove around Muscat in large motorcades of up to 200 cars.{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iAymzdbdndBVAczRpJ13-_iQbPCg?docId=CNG.4103fec93a330f1c195d92e86c2ce8c3.281|title=Pro-sultan Omanis in support drive|publisher=Google News|date=2 March 2011|accessdate=28 March 2011|agency=Agence France-Presse}}[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/omani-tweep-who-told-the-sohar-story-1.770405 Omani tweep who told the Sohar story]. ''Gulf News'', (2 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. In early March, rallies in support of the Sultan continued to be staged. ==Responses== ===Domestic=== The [[Sultan Qaboos|Sultan of Oman]] cancelled a visit to India as a result of the unrest in the Arab world.{{cite news|author=Indrani Bagchi|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-02-18/india/28614653_1_sultan-qaboos-ruler-oman |title=Egypt fallout: Oman ruler postpones India trip|work=The Times of India|date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=1 March 2011}} On 26 February, the sultan reshuffled the cabinet in response to recent protests. The 84-member [[Consultative Assembly of Oman|Shura council]] is elected by voters across 61 districts, but works in a purely advisory capacity and has no legislative powers. The cabinet reshuffle saw [[Mohammed bin Nasser al-Khasibi]] named commerce and industry minister, [[Hamoud bin Faisal al-Bousaidi]] as civil service minister and [[Madiha bint Ahmed bin Nasser]] as education minister. Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Abdullah al-Harthy]], the outgoing civil service minister, was appointed to head the environment ministry, while [[Maqboul bin Ali bin Sultan]] will be the new transport minister and [[Mohsen bin Mohammed al-Sheikh]] becomes tourism minister. Protesters had called upon the Sultan to remove [[Maqbool Bin Ali Bin Sultan]] from the post of commerce minister as they viewed him as corrupt and inadequate for the task of running the ministry.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/sultan-qaboos-reshuffles-oman-cabinet-1.768277 |title=Sultan Qaboos reshuffles Oman cabinet |work=Gulf News |accessdate=1 March 2011}} The Sultan also announced benefits for the students of [[Higher College of Technology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/February/middleeast_February780.xml§ion=middleeast |title=Oman takes measures to address public grievances |publisher=Khaleejtimes.com |accessdate=1 March 2011}} The students whose homes are 100 km away from the place of study, will be now given 90 [[Omani rial]] allowances while those living at a less than 100-km distance would get 25-rial allowance. The Royal decree issued stated the reason for the rise in these stipends as "to achieve further development and provide a decent living." The [[Diwan of Royal Court]], on the orders of the sultan, decided to set up an independent authority for consumer protection in the country. It has also been decided to study the possibility of establishing cooperative societies in the country which does not allow formation of any political parties, unions, etc. whatsoever. There are also confirmed plans to reduce the percentage contribution of civil servants in the Civil Employees Pension Fund from eight percent to seven percent of the monthly basic salary, adding to it 75 percent of the housing, electricity and water allowances. On 28 February, Sultan Qaboos pledged to create 50,000 government jobs, provide a monthly benefit of $390 to the unemployed and ordered a committee to draft proposals for boosting the power of an elected council that advises him on state affairs.{{cite news|last=Charmelot|first=Jacques|date=27 February 2011|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iEbFoiaf3y5011Vp3yrALFAa0kjQ?docId=CNG.3bcc0040b48d45bb31070d5319019b17.121|title=Oil-rich Arab states open their coffers|publisher=Google News|access-date=28 March 2011|agency=Agence France-Presse}} He also promised that a legislative council would be given more powers. On 5 March, Sultan Qaboos replaced two more ministers. [[Khaled bin Hilal bin Saud al-Busaidi]] replaced [[Sayed Ali bin Hmud al-Busaidi]] as a minister of the royal court and [[Sultan bin Mohammed al-Numani]] replaced General [[Ali bin Majid al-Maamari]] as minister in the sultan's office.{{cite news |title=Oman's ruler dismisses ministers |author=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/03/20113565533194678.html |date=5 March 2011 |access-date=5 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110305093031/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/03/20113565533194678.html| archivedate= 5 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 7 March, Sultan Qaboos issued eight royal decrees including, reshuffling once again the council of ministers and allowing for the formation of a state audit committee. Royal Decree No 38/2011 abolished the Ministry of National Economy and states that a committee shall be formed by the Council of Ministers to manage the distribution of its prerogatives, allocations, assets and employees. The ministry had been targeted by protesters for being corrupt and inefficient.[http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/2011030710133/Oman-Politics/oman-sultan-qaboos-restructures-council-of-ministers.html Oman: Sultan Qaboos Restructures Cabinet Ministers | Oman Politics] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121208202039/http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/2011030710133/Oman-Politics/oman-sultan-qaboos-restructures-council-of-ministers.html |date=8 December 2012 }}. [[Global Arab Network]] (7 March 2011). Retrieved 28 March 2011. On 13 March, a royal decree was announced granting "legislative and regulatory powers" to the parliament, which had previously only been a consultative body.[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/qaboos-gives-legislative-powers-to-council-of-oman-1.775709 Qaboos gives legislative powers to Council of Oman]. ''Gulf News'', (13 March 2011). Retrieved 28 March 2011. The next day he fired Lieutenant General [[Malek Bin Sulaiman Al Ma'amari]] as Inspector General of the Police and Customs.[http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/sultan-qaboos-fires-omans-police-chief Sultan Qaboos fires Oman's police chief] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316163345/http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/sultan-qaboos-fires-omans-police-chief |date=16 March 2011 }}. ''The National''. Retrieved 28 March 2011. On 15 March, he also issued further [[royal decree]]s to add a "cost of living allowance" to all military and security apparatus as well as all government units in Oman.[http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=42161&rand=EMxwVAelcGNCR4KVVGWDH2Bh6G His Majesty issues Royal Orders] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717060416/http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=42161&rand=EMxwVAelcGNCR4KVVGWDH2Bh6G |date=17 July 2011 }}. ''Times of Oman'' (15 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. The Sultan also give orders for raising the Social Insurance Pension by 100% for all the 51,442 persons registered at the Social Development Ministry.[http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=42141 His Orders issued for raising Social Insurance Pension] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717060420/http://www.timesofoman.com/innercat.asp?detail=42141 |date=17 July 2011 }}. ''Times of Oman'' (14 March 2011). Retrieved 28 March 2011. The ruling council issued a statement that condemned the "sabotage" and added that peaceful demonstrations were within "the legal rights of citizens".{{cite news|last=Bakri|first=Nada|title=Protests in Oman Spread From Port City to Capital|work=The New York Times|date=1 March 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/01/world/middleeast/01oman.html}} Other responses included creating of a second public university,[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?col=§ion=middleeast&xfile=data/middleeast/2011/May/middleeast_May52.xml Oman to decentralise power, implement reforms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121001184338/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?col=§ion=middleeast&xfile=data%2Fmiddleeast%2F2011%2FMay%2Fmiddleeast_May52.xml |date=1 October 2012 }}. ''Khaleej Times'', (4 May 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. establishing the first Islamic bank in the region[http://www.emirates247.com/business/bank-nizwa-is-oman-s-first-islamic-bank-2011-05-16-1.393394 Bank Nizwa is Oman's first Islamic bank]. Emirates 24/7. Retrieved 2012-01-15. and approving Marriage Fund utility.[http://www.khaleejtimes.com/displayarticle.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/May/middleeast_May828.xml§ion=middleeast&col Oman gives final shape to report on marriage fund]. ''Khaleej Times'', (30 May 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. The popular response to the actions of Qaboos was said to be positive, particularly in light of the decision to grant the Council of Oman more powers. Hussain Al Abry, who was a lone protester against [[Oman Television]] for four days, said that "Sixty to 80 percent of demands have already been met so there is no reason to continue protesting."[http://m.gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/protesters-in-oman-happy-with-qaboos-decision-to-give-council-of-oman-powers-1.776309 Protesters in Oman happy with Qaboos’ decision to give Council of Oman powers]. ''[[Gulf News]]'', (13 March 2011). Retrieved 2012-01-15. ====Apolitical==== The [[Muscat Securities Market]]'s main index fell 4.9 percent.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/business/markets/regional-markets-extend-losses-as-unrest-grows-1.769417 |title=Regional markets extend losses as unrest grows |work=Gulf News |date=28 January 2009 |access-date=1 March 2011}} Neighbouring United Arab Emirates' two main stock markets in [[Dubai Financial Market|Dubai]] and [[Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange|Abu Dhabi]] also fell as the instability moved to the countries of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]].{{cite news|last=Lohade |first=Nikhil |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704615504576172241374081256 |title=Gulf Markets Dive as Unrest Spreads |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=28 February 2011|access-date=1 March 2011}} The [[Sohar Industrial Port Company]] said that the local port's functions were never disrupted by more than a few hours during periods of traffic problems caused by the protests.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ===International=== ;Supranational bodies {{flagicon|Gulf Cooperation Council}} [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] members agreed to provide Oman with an aid plan similar to the [[Marshall plan]], consisting of $10 billion aimed at upgrading housing and infrastructure over a period of 10 years.{{cite news |title=Sectarian clashes at Bahrain school |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011310201330454225.html|date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110312165846/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011310201330454225.html| archivedate= 12 March 2011 | deadurl= no}} They also agreed that they would give more preference to GCC-member state nationals while hiring individuals.[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/gcc-marshall-style-aid-package-for-bahrain-oman-1.770473 GCC marshall-style aid package for Bahrain, Oman]. ''Gulf News'', (2 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. ;States {{Flagu|India}} – The embassy issued a notice to all their citizens currently residing in Oman (estimated at more than 300,000) to register themselves with the embassy. It also requested them to avoid taking part in any pro-government or anti-government rallies and steer clear of any kind of trouble.[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/oman/indians-urged-to-be-on-guard-by-mission-in-oman-1.770511 Indians urged to be on guard by mission in Oman]. ''Gulf News'', (2 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. {{Flagu|Netherlands}} – [[Queen Beatrix]] had originally postponed a state visit to Oman amidst the crisis.[https://web.archive.org/web/20121112040713/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/02/AR2011030203039.html ] The visit later went ahead but was downgraded to a private visit amidst several political parties expressing concern the royal could be seen as supportive of the unelected sultan. Parliament will debate the matter on Tuesday.[http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/oman-protests-continue-ahead-royal-visit Oman protests continue ahead of royal visit | Radio Netherlands Worldwide] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310160334/http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/oman-protests-continue-ahead-royal-visit# |date=10 March 2011 }}. Rnw.nl (6 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. {{Flagu|United Kingdom}} – The British embassy in Oman issued a notice to all British citizens in the country to avoid visiting Sohar as the situation in the city was tense.[https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-ateiW7W0WGg/TWtBqXJHplI/AAAAAAAAJ_I/Ccq0-FF_ANc/s1600/Wardens+notice+27+Feb+11.jpg Wardens Note], British Embassy Muscat, 28 February 2011 {{Flagu|United States}} – The U.S. State Department spokesman [[Philip J. Crowley|P.J. Crowley]] told reporters the U.S. encouraged the [[government of Oman]] to show restraint and resolve differences through dialogue. "We have been in touch with the government and encouraged restraint and to resolve differences through dialogue. We are encouraged by the recent steps toward reform taken by the government of Oman, and we strongly encourage the government to implement reforms that increase economic opportunity and move toward greater inclusion and participation in the political process."[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hRTqyfhpSPpVTcY8OU8K8bYlGYKg?docId=CNG.b5aedb71894a12facb3ae790ca3ef931.891 AFP: US encouraged by Oman's reform moves]. Google. (7 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. ;NGOs [[Amnesty International]] has requested and urged the Omani government to show restraint while dealing with protesters.[http://www.sify.com/news/oman-urged-not-to-use-excessive-force-against-protesters-news-international-ldbq4wadbee.html "Oman urged not to use excessive force against protesters"]. Sify.com (1 March 2011). Retrieved 2011-03-28. ==See also== {{commons category|2011 Omani protests}} *[[Dhofar Rebellion]] *[[List of countries by unemployment rate|World unemployment rates]] *[[Corruption Perceptions Index]] *[[Freedom in the World]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://en.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-476/_nr-1495/i.html Sultan Qaboos bin Said: Oman's Renaissance Man] {{Arab Spring}} {{Anti-government protests in the 21st century}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2011 Omani Protests}} [[Category:Arab Spring by country|Oman protests, 2011]] [[Category:2011 in Oman|Protests]] [[Category:2011 protests|Omani]] [[Category:Rebellions in Oman]] [[Category:21st century in Muscat, Oman]] [[Category:Sohar]]

{{Infobox news event | title = 2014 Pathum Thani building collapse | date = 11 August 2014 | time = 16:20 [[UTC+7]]{{cite web|title=วิศวกรรมสถานแห่งประเทศไทยฯ วิเคราะห์สาเหตุอาคารคอนโด 6 ชั้น คลอง 6 พังถล่ม|url=http://eitprblog.blogspot.com/2014/08/6-6.html|website=Engineering Institute of Thailand|accessdate=15 August 2014}} | place = [[Pathum Thani province]]
[[Thailand]] | reported injuries = 25{{cite news|title=Final building collapse death toll 14|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/most-recent/426881/rescuers-end-search-of-collapsed-u-place-condo-rubble|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=[[Bangkok Post]]|publisher=The Post Publishing PCL|date=15 August 2014}} | reported death(s) = 14 }} On 11 August 2014, a six-story building under construction in the '''''U Place Condotel condominium''''' project, collapsed in [[Pathum Thani province]], [[Thailand]]. The collapse resulted in 14 deaths and 25 injuries to the construction workers working on the building. == Background == The collapse building was part of a six building project, including two finished buildings with residents. The building project is owned by Plook Plang Co. Ltd. == Aftermath == Casualties included [[Cambodia]]n nationals who were construction workers.{{cite news|last1=Sokheng|first1=Vong|last2=Barron|first2=Laignee|title=Bodies pulled from rubble|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/bodies-pulled-rubble|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=[[The Phnom Penh Post]]|date=15 August 2014}} The rescue operation was concluded on 14 August 2014, after all victims were found. == Cause == A flaw in the construction design was cited as the cause for collapse. [[Column]]s at the perimeter of the building were not strong enough to support the weight of cement being poured on the roof, leading to a structural failure.{{cite news|title=Police arrest 4 over collapse|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/426646/police-arrest-4-over-collapse|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=[[Bangkok Post]]|publisher=The Post Publishing PCL|date=15 August 2014}} == See also == *[[Collapse of the Royal Plaza Hotel]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord missing|Thailand}} [[Category:Building collapses in 2014]] [[Category:Man-made disasters in Thailand]] [[Category:2014 industrial disasters]] [[Category:2014 in Thailand]] [[Category:August 2014 events]] [[Category:Pathum Thani Province]] [[Category:Building collapses]]
