183,000 displaced (per United Nations){{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-turkey/kurds-offer-joint-border-deployment-as-iraq-threatens-more-military-operations-idUSKBN1D20GA|title=Kurds offer joint border deployment as Iraq threatens more military operations|publisher=Reuters|date=2 November 2017}} }} {{Campaignbox Kurdish–Iraqi conflict}} {{Campaignbox Iraq War (2014–present)}} The '''2017 Iraqi–Kurdish conflict''' occurred in and around the [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdish region]] of northern [[Iraq]], and began on 15 October 2017, as a result of the [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|Iraqi Kurdistan referendum in 2017]] held on September{{nbsp}}25. The diplomatic crisis between the [[Federal government of Iraq|Iraqi Government]] and the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] (KRG) escalated into all out conflict when the [[Peshmerga]] ignored repeated warnings by Iraqi prime minister [[Haider al-Abadi]] to hand over Kirkuk peacefully to Iraqi forces. The Peshmerga stated they would not take commands from the central Government of Iraq but from the autonomous Kurdish region, this was tantamount to a declaration of rebellion against the state of Iraq. After a several weeks stand-off at the gates of Kirkuk, Iraqi troops were given orders to attack on 15 October. Despite having a significant disadvantage in terms of numbers, the attacking force was superior in equipment and discipline, and had effective tactics and coordination.{{cite news|author=|title=After all but defeating the jihadists, Iraq’s army turns on the Kurds|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21730417-dreams-independent-kurdistan-are-now-tatters-after-all-defeating|work=[[The Economist]]|date=21 October 2017}}The Peshmerga were routed from the entire city of Kirkuk within a day and the Iraqi army pushed further north ejecting the Peshmerga from the entirety of Kirkuk province and neighbouring [[Sinjar]], [[Diyala Governorate|Diyala]] and the Nineva plains.. The conflict marked a major set-back in Kurdish hopes for an independent nation as the KRG had lost 40 percent of land under its jurisdiction and their main source of revenue, the kirkuk oil fields. This meant the KRG was now reliant on an annual budget from the central government. The KRG made to sign a pledge to not seek independence again as a precondition to the end of the conflict. {{cite news|title=Kerkük'te Türkmenler güvenliklerini kendileri sağlamaya başladı|url=http://aa.com.tr/tr/dunya/kerkukte-turkmenler-guvenliklerini-kendileri-saglamaya-basladi/939408|work=Anadolu Ajansı}} ==Background== {{main article|Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017}} The [[President of the Kurdistan Region|President of the Iraqi Kurdistan Region]], [[Masoud Barzani]], facilitated the [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum in September 2017]]. This provoked the [[Prime Minister of Iraq]] [[Haider al-Abadi]] to demand that the referendum result be cancelled, and called on the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|KRG]] to initiate dialogue "in the framework of the constitution".{{cite news|title=Iraqi PM calls on Kurdistan to cancel referendum, start dialogue|url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/iraqi-pm-calls-on-kurdistan-to-cancel-referendum-start-dialogue/50000260-3391820|work=www.efe.com|language=en}} In October, Iraq began to move its forces into areas seized by the [[Kurdistan Regional Government|KRG]] after the entry of ISIL, and all the disputed areas outside the Kurdish Region, including Kirkuk.{{cite web|title=خطة انتشار القوات العراقية في المناطق المتنازع عليها مع كردستان|url=https://arabic.sputniknews.com/arab_world/201710181026854198-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%82%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%82-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B2%D8%B9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%87%D8%A7-%D9%85%D8%B9-%D9%83%D8%B1%D8%AF%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86/}}{{cite web|title=الحشد الشعبي: لا بد أن تنسحب البشمركة لحدود 2003|url=https://arabic.sputniknews.com/arab_world/201710241026978762-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%B4%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%B9%D8%A8%D9%8A-%D9%84%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D8%AF-%D8%AA%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AD%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%A9-%D8%AD%D9%88%D8%AF%D9%88-2003/}} ==Battle of Kirkuk== {{see also|Battle of Kirkuk (2017)}} The Kurdish [[Peshmerga]] ignored a deadline given by Iraq to withdraw by 15{{nbsp}}October 2017. This led to the Iraqi forces and the [[Popular Mobilization Forces|PMU militia]] retaking Kirkuk and its province on the same day. Within 15 hours, the city of [[Kirkuk]] and the nearby [[K-1 Air Base]], along with surrounding oilfields, were retaken by Iraqi forces.{{cite news|title=Baghdad: Iraqi forces in full control of Kirkuk|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/baghdad-iraqi-forces-full-control-kirkuk-171016133409720.html|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=www.aljazeera.com|date=16 October 2017}} The international coalition described the events as "...coordinated movements, not attacks...", with most Peshmerga withdrawing without much of a fight.{{cite news|title=Coalition Statement on Military Movements Near Kirkuk|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/News-Releases/Article/1343292/coalition-statement-on-military-movements-near-kirkuk/|work=Operation Inherent Resolve}} This was likely due to the fact that Hero and Bafel Talabani, leaders of the PUK Peshmerga, struck a deal with the Iraqis to withdraw without a fight without notifying the KDP Peshmerga. This, in turn, led to the collapse of Kurdish defenses, and led to accusations of betrayal on part of the Talabani family by the KDP, since the day before the battle of Kirkuk both parties met in Dukan and agreed to fight.{{cite news|title=Mutual accusations after the withdrawal|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/181020171}} The same day, Iraqi forces advanced on and captured the city of [[Tuz Khurmatu]] in the [[Saladin Province]], 60 km south of Kirkuk,{{cite news|title=Baghdad forces seize Tuz Khurmatu amid Kirkuk operation|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/baghdad-forces-seize-tuz-khurmatu-amid-kirkuk-operation/938885|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=Anadolu Agency|date=16 October 2017}} as well as [[Kifri]] in the [[Diyala Governorate]].{{cite news|title=Peshmerga to withdraw from Dilaya governorate – Egypt Today|url=https://www.egypttoday.com/Article/1/27939/Peshmerga-to-withdraw-from-Dilaya-governorate|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=Egypt Today|date=16 October 2017}} On 17{{nbsp}}October 2017, [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] attacked the villages of Makha, and Twelha, just north of Kirkuk.{{cite news|title=ISIS attacks two villages north of Kirkuk|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/161020174}} The Iraqi advance also continued, with further gains including [[Khanaqin]] near the Iranian border as well as [[Jalawla]], [[Bashiqa]] and [[Sinjar]] towards Syria.{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Loveday|last2=El-Ghobashy|first2=Tamer|last3=Shwan|first3=Aaso Ameen|title=Iraqi forces move deeper into Kurdish-held areas, redrawing political map|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/iraqi-forces-take-back-sinjar-in-latest-effort-to-roll-back-kurdish-gains-of-the-past-years/2017/10/17/61032770-b30d-11e7-9e58-e6288544af98_story.html|accessdate=17 October 2017|work=Washington Post|date=17 October 2017}} A statement from the Iraqi military on 18{{nbsp}}October, 2017, confirmed that the [[Mosul dam]] and other previously Kurdish-held territories in [[Nineveh province]] had been taken from the Peshmerga.{{cite news|title=Iraqi forces take control of Kurdish-held areas in Mosul's Nineveh's province|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-nineveh/iraqi-forces-take-control-of-kurdish-held-areas-in-mosuls-nivevehs-province-idUSKBN1CN0HZ?il=0|accessdate=18 October 2017|work=Reuters|date=18 October 2017}} Ali Akbar Khafaji, an Iraqi police officer, claimed eight PMU fighters and one Peshmerga fighter were killed in clashes that broke out after the PMU failed to heed the Peshmerga's warnings to not advance on the Mosul dam.{{cite news|title=Iraq: 9 killed in clashes near Mosul dam|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/iraq-9-killed-in-clashes-near-mosul-dam/940661|accessdate=18 October 2017|work=Anadolu Agency|date=23 October 2017}} By 19{{nbsp}}October 2017, according to Erbil's governor, 100,000 ethnic Kurds had fled the city of Kirkuk and Tuz Khurmatu following the victory by Iraqi forces, with 18,000 Kurds taking shelter in Erbil and Suleimaniya.{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-refugees/about-100000-kurds-have-fled-kirkuk-since-monday-kurdish-officials-idUSKBN1CO13D |title=About 100,000 Kurds have fled Kirkuk since Monday: Kurdish officials |agency= Reuters |date= 19 October 2017}} The next day, Hemin Hawrami, a senior assistant to KRG President Masoud Barzani, said in a post on Twitter that 57,000 families from Kirkuk were in need of "immediate assistance" after arriving in various parts of Iraqi Kurdistan and taking shelter in unfinished housing units, having fled from "violence, looting and crimes" perpetrated by the Iranian-trained and largely Shi'ite [[Popular Mobilization Forces]].{{cite news |url= http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/000-flee-kirkuk-iraqi-army-takeover-171019215041252.html |title= '100,000 flee Kirkuk' since Iraqi army takeover |agency= Al Jazeera |date= 20 October 2017}} Kirkuk police called on the media not to publish rumors.{{cite news|title=شرطة كركوك: سنثبت دوريات في المناطق الكردية لمنع النزوح منها بفعل الشائعات|url=http://www.nrttv.com/Ar/Detail.aspx?Jimare=61672|work=nrttv.com}} The [[United Nations]] released a statement saying it was concerned about reports of violence and the forced displacement of Kurdish civilians,{{cite news |url= https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/u-n-concerned-alleged-deportations-assaults-kurds-kirkuk/ |title= U.N. concerned over alleged assaults on Kurds in Kirkuk |author= Mohamed Mostafa |agency=Iraqi News |date=19 October 2017}} and called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice.{{cite news |title= UPDATE 1-UN concerned by reports of forced displacement of Kurds in N. Iraq |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-violations/update-1-un-concerned-by-reports-of-forced-diplacement-of-kurds-in-niraq-idUSL8N1MU57Y |agency= Reuters |date= 19 October 2017}} It was further reported that UN relief offices received reports that in the town of Tuz Khurmatu, 150 houses were burned and 11 houses were blown up. The UN noted PM Haider al-Abadi's acknowledgement of incidents in Tuz Khurmatu, caused by what he described as extremist elements from both sides and his decision to send the Iraqi army to restore order in Tuz Khurmatu, as well as the requests of the political and security leaderships of the country for federal and local security forces to act in full respect for law and order and protect civilians and political leaders.{{cite news|title=UN Expresses Concern about Reports of Violence in Tuz Khurmatu, in Kirkuk [EN/AR/KU]|url=https://reliefweb.int/report/iraq/un-expresses-concern-about-reports-violence-tuz-khurmatu-kirkuk-enarku|work=ReliefWeb|date=19 October 2017|language=en}} The PM accused social media instigators of posting fake videos of the alleged violations. The Niqash website confirmed this increase of false news, as well as hundreds of fake videos & pictures. Leaders on both sides say this is leading to a dangerous escalation of tensions in northern Iraq.{{cite news|last1=Qader|first1=Histyar|title=Dangerous Growth Of Fake News Increases Tensions In Northern Iraq|url=http://www.niqash.org/en/articles/security/5763/|work=Niqash|language=en}} On 19{{nbsp}}October 2017, one person was killed and three wounded in a protest against Iraqi forces in Khanaqin city. A group of about 150 to 200 unarmed youth carrying Kurdistan flags were protesting, demanding that Iraqi forces leave the city, Col. Azad Isa, Khanaqin's police chief, told [[Rudaw Media Network|Rudaw Kurdish Network]].{{cite news|title=One killed, three wounded in protest in Khanaqin|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/191020177}} The demonstration was small but energetic, ending with some dancing before they all left. Many said they just wanted the local police to have a presence in town and were not concerned with the larger political struggle over Kurdish independence.{{cite news|title=Sensationalized news is fueling tension over areas disputed between Iraqis and Kurds|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/10/19/sensationalized-news-is-fueling-tension-over-areas-disputed-between-iraqis-and-kurds/|work=Washington Post|date=19 October 2017}} On 20{{nbsp}}October 2017, a battle took place in [[Altun Kupri]] as Iraqi forces moved towards it.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/20/middleeast/kirkuk-iraq-peshmerga/index.html|title=Iraqi forces clash with Kurdish fighters in town north of Kirkuk|work=CNN|access-date=2017-10-22}} Iraq's Joint Operations Command stated that Peshmerga had used [[MILAN]] missiles in the battle, which led to Iraqi criticism as the missiles were given by Germany to the Peshmerga in order to be used against ISIL. The Peshmerga denied they had used the missiles.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/211020175|title=Peshmerga deny using MILAN anti-tank system against Iraqi forces|work=Rudaw|access-date=2017-10-22}} Earlier, Germany had said it would temporarily stop training Kurdish Peshmerga forces.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-army-restarts-training-iraqi-kurds-but-future-of-mission-in-doubt/a-41070521|title=German army restarts training Iraqi Kurds, but future of mission in doubt|work=Deustche-Welle|access-date=2017-10-22}} However, training began again after a week's interruption.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nrttv.com/EN/Details.aspx?Jimare=17151|title=GERMANY RESTARTS TRAINING MISSION FOR PESHMERGA AFTER A WEEK PAUSE|website=www.nrttv.com|access-date=2017-10-25}} Kurdish sources also reported that over 150 PMU fighters were killed or wounded.{{cite news|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/20102017|title=Iraqi army, Shiite militia and Peshmerga exchange heavy fire north of Kirkuk |work=[[Rudaw Media Network|Rudaw]] |date=21 October 2017}} This was considered to be the first significant battle in which the Peshmerga put up a heavy resistance, whereas in other disputed areas they withdrew after the arrival of Iraqi forces.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/20102017|title=Iraqi army, Shiite militia and Peshmerga exchange heavy fire north of Kirkuk|work=Rudaw|access-date=2017-10-22}} By the end of 20{{nbsp}}October Iraqi forces have seized complete control of Kirkuk province.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/iraq-forces-full-control-kirkuk-province-171021044707969.html|title=Iraq forces in full control of Kirkuk province|publisher=Al-Jazeera}} Iraqi Joint Operations Command (JOC) meanwhile denied that Hashd al-Shaabi (PMU) fighters were present among the troops that advanced on Altan Kupri, claiming the troops were Counter-Terrorism Service (CTS) forces. It added that two soldiers were killed and five others wounded in the clashes that erupted when they captured the town.{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/21/c_136696343.htm|title=2 soldiers killed in Iraq's Altun Kupri clashes: military|publisher=Xinhua News Agency}} ==Subsequent events== On 24{{nbsp}}October 2017, Peshmerga KDP forces were told that the checkpoint in [[Makhmur, Iraq|Makhmur]] would be handed over as per agreements between the Iraqi government and the Kurdish Regional government. However, upon arrival at the checkpoint, the Peshmerga surrounded the Iraqi troops. Twenty Iraqi soldiers were arrested,{{cite news|title=Enmity Between Baghdad and Kurds Erupts in Deadly Clashes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/24/world/middleeast/iraqi-kurds-clashes-abadi.html|work=The New York Times}} two killed, and eight more were wounded by the Peshmerga.{{cite news|title=Kurdish Peshmerga use Iraqi flags on their position to ambush Iraqi unit, executing 2 of them {{!}} Al Sura|url=http://al-sura.com/peshmerga-use-iraqi-flags-to-ambush-iraqi-unit-executing-2-of-them/|accessdate=25 October 2017}} The [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan|PUK]] accused the [[Peshmerga|Peshmerga KDP]] of mistreating those who had been arrested by them,{{cite news|title=PUK Media:- KDP Peshmerga is mistreating the PMU Militants who have been arrested by them in Makhmour|url=https://twitter.com/LawkGhafuri/status/922839998432464896|work=gksat.tv کەناڵی ئاسمانی گەلی کوردستان}} and all Iraqi soldiers were released after the Peshmerga command intervened against a local Peshmerga garrison acting against orders.{{cite web|title=Paramilitary troops deny attacking Peshmerga near Erbil|url=https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/paramilitary-troops-deny-attacking-peshmerga-near-erbil/}} On 25{{nbsp}}October 2017, Iraqi forces seized the [[Rabia, Iraq|Rabia]] border crossing with Syria after the withdrawal of Syrian Kurdish forces.{{cite news|title=Iraqi army retakes a strategic border crossing with Syria|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/iraqi-army-retakes-strategic-border-crossing-with-syria/947782|work=Anadolu Agency}} On the same day, the KRG made a statement offering to freeze the results of the referendum as part of an offer to defuse the crisis. The statement also called for a ceasefire and a halt to all military operations in the northern region.{{cite news|title=Iraqi Kurdistan offers to freeze referendum results to defuse the crisis with Baghdad|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/25/iraqi-Kurdistan-offers-freeze-referendum-results-defuse-crisis-with-baghdad.html|publisher=CNBC}} Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi rejected the proposal, adding that the Iraqi central government "will accept only the canceling of the referendum and following the constitution."{{cite news|title=Iraq dismisses Kurdish offer to 'freeze' independence vote|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/iraqi-premier-iran-recent-visits-turkey-jordan-50728078|publisher=ABC News}} On 26{{nbsp}}October 2017 at 06:00 hrs, Iraqi federal police and Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF) began a four-pronged assault on Peshmerga positions in [[Zummar]]; from Bardiya and Hamad Agha towards Ain Ouais, from Mosharaf towards Sufaya, and from Rabia towards Mahmoudiya.{{cite news|title=Peshmerga repel Shia militias assault on four fronts: Kurdistan Security Council|url=http://www.kurdistan24.net/en/news/dba673ec-6204-45e7-9135-87fe5bebfd1a|work=[[Kurdistan 24]]|language=en}} The Kurdistan Security Council claimed that Peshmerga had destroyed three tanks, five US-supplied Humvees and one Badger and repelled the attempts of the Iraqi forces to retake Faysh Khabur.{{cite news|title=Peshmerga respond to, push back Iraqi militia attack near Zummar|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/2510201710|work=Rudaw}} However, Iraqi forces and PMU militia managed to retake two villages, Jazronia & Mahmoudiya, as they attempted to advance towards the town of [[Faysh Khabur]], near the Iraqi-Syrian-Turkish border triangle.{{cite news|title=Iraqi forces clash with Kurdish Peshmerga in disputed areas – Xinhua English.news.cn|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/26/c_136708101.htm}}{{cite news|title=القوات الاتحادية تعيد انتشارها في قرية المحمودية شمال غرب الموصل|url=http://www.nrttv.com/AR/Details.aspx?Jimare=62277|work=nrttv.com}} Some reports meanwhile indicated that Masoud Barzani might announce that he would step down as president of the KRG.{{cite news|title=Iraqi Kurd leader Barzani may step down, a potential blow to his ruling family|url=http://www.newsweek.com/iraq-new-war-kurd-leader-barzani-may-step-down-keep-power-family-693217|work=Newsweek|date=26 October 2017|language=en}} On 27{{nbsp}}October, the Kurdish Regional Government stated that Iraqi forces and Kurdish Peshmerga fighters had agreed to stop fighting in northern Iraq, although the status of any ceasefire remained unclear. A [[CJTF-OIR]] spokesman earlier said the deal covered all fronts of conflict. However, he later denied that truce had been officially agreed.{{cite news|title=Iraqi forces, Kurdish Peshmerga agreed on a ceasefire, U.S.-led coalition says|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-ceasefire/iraqi-forces-kurdish-peshmerga-agree-on-ceasefire-u-s-led-coalition-says-idUSKBN1CW1LG|work=Reuters|date=27 October 2017}} The coalition's spokesman, Col. Ryan Dillon, denied that a ceasefire had been reached, retreating from his earlier announcement of a ceasefire between both sides, [[Twitter|tweeting]], "I incorrectly said in an interview with (Kurdish TV) Rudaw English that there was a cease-fire between Iraqi and Kurdish forces."{{cite news|title=U.S.-led coalition says no Iraqi-Kurdish cease-fire reached|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/27/c_136710677.htm|work=Xinhua News Agency}} Iraqi PM al-Abadi later ordered a 24-hour truce to allow a peaceful deployment of Iraqi troops at border crossings with the Kurdistan region.{{cite news|title=Iraq orders truce with Kurds to allow peaceful deployment at border crossings|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-ceasefire-p/iraq-orders-truce-with-kurds-to-allow-peaceful-deployment-at-border-crossings-idUSKBN1CW26D|work=Reuters|date=27 October 2017}} On 29{{nbsp}}November, after claims of ethnic cleansing and the destruction of Kurdish homes, shops and businesses in Tuz Khurmatu and claims of discrimination and oppression against the Kurdish residents of the city by the PMU.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/291120174|title=Residents describe Khanaqin as city in mourning|last=|first=|date=|website=www.rudaw.net|access-date=2017-12-13}} The 'Kurdistan Liberation Army' was formed composing of 200 Kurdish volunteers in Tuz Khurmatu. Clashes occurred, in which 8 PMU fighters were killed, and one Kurdish volunteer wounded.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/291120179|title=Kurdish ‘Liberation Army’ threatens to attack Hashd in Tuz Khurmatu|last=|first=|date=|website=www.rudaw.net|access-date=2017-12-13}} Kurdistan24 posted footage of the fighting{{Cite news|url=http://www.kurdistan24.net/so/news/633824e0-0461-4aa7-98dd-e7a6ee6ee7dd|title=به‌ ڤيديۆ‌.. شه‌ڕه‌كه‌ى ئه‌مڕۆى خورماتوو ببينه‌|last=Kurdistan24|work=Kurdistan24|access-date=2017-12-13}} and unverified graphic videos showed dead bodies of the Turkmen PMU stationed in Tuz Khurmatu. There had been clashes in Kirkuk between volunteers nearly every day in the previous month between Kurdish volunteers and PMU. A thread on Twitter has posted videos of these clashes.{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AramKrdstn/status/934497838188388352|title=Clashes outside #Kirkuk, between the City and Laylan. No Infos about casualties and attackers.pic.twitter.com/tCQ7NBBMQL|last=Aram|date=2017-11-25|website=@AramKrdstn|language=en|access-date=2017-12-13}} On 6{{nbsp}}December a policeman, Major Samer Abdel Nabi Jassam, was killed in a drive-by shooting in Kirkuk city, presumembly by DRK.{{Cite web|url=https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/policeman-killed-drive-shooting-kirkuk/|title=Police officer killed in drive-by shooting in Kirkuk city|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} A day later, heavy fighting erupted in Kirkuk in which the DRK targeted an Iraqi Counter-Terrorism HQ with heavy weapons, RPG'S, grenades and rifle fire; the battle lasting an hour. Afrasiaw Kamil Waisi, Kirkuk police spokesperson stated that there was no casualties,{{Cite web|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/iraq/071220173|title=Fighting in Kirkuk, unknown gunmen target Iraqi Counter-Terror post|last=|first=|date=|website=www.rudaw.net|access-date=2017-12-13}} however other Kurdish sources claimed many Iraqi troops were killed and wounded.{{Cite news|url=http://www.basnews.com/index.php/en/news/kurdistan/398278|title=Iraqi Forces, Shi’ite Militias Under Fierce Attack in Kirkuk – basnews|last=English|first=Basnews|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en-gb}} On 12{{nbsp}}December Iraqi helicopters bombed Dawouda and Zinana areas (Kurdish areas) for the first time since 1991 causing many Kurdish families to be displaced. This led to DRK retaliatory mortar fire against PMU forces inside Tuz Khurmatu causing many casualties amongst the PMU forces.http://www.rudaw.net/english/kurdistan/121220172 On 16{{nbsp}}December a heavy firefight occurred after Kurdish volunteers inside Kirkuk used at least 5 RPG's and heavy weapons against 2 different Turkmen offices. Turkmen sources claim there were no casualties.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/todays-news/196951/iraqi-turkmen-front-offices-attacked-in-kirkuk|title=Iraqi Turkmen Front offices attacked in Kirkuk - World Bulletin|publisher=|accessdate=3 April 2018}} A day later, on 18{{nbsp}}December, some Kurds in Kirkuk flew the Kurdish flag in schools and universities in Kirkuk and wore Kurdish clothes to celebrate the official Kurdistan Flag Day, leading to PMF forces arresting a number of young people involved.https://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/three-kurdish-students-arrested-pmfs-wearing/ ==Dialogue== {{see|Two-state solution (Iraqi–Kurdish negotiations)}} Iraqi and Peshmerga commanders held talks in Mosul on 28{{nbsp}}October attempting to resolve the crisis over the disputed areas.{{cite news|title=Iraqi Kurdish commanders hold talks on disputed areas|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/story/569139/Iraqi-Kurdish-commanders-hold-talks-on-disputed-ar|work=Gulf Times|date=29 October 2017}} Amidst the crisis, KRG President Masoud Barzani announced on 29 October that he would not be asking parliament to renew his presidency when it expired on 1{{nbsp}}November, transferring his presidential powers to the institutions of the KRG which include the legislature and judiciary.{{cite news|title=Iraqi Kurdistan leader Barzani will hand over presidential powers on November 1|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/29/iraqi-kurdistan-leader-masoud-barzani-will-hand-over-presidential-powers-on-november-1.html|work=CNBC|date=29 October 2017}} Iraqi state TV meanwhile said that the second round of talks between both sides had started the same day.{{cite news|title=Iraqi forces, Kurdish Peshmerga start new round of talks, Iraqi State TV says|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-talks/iraqi-forces-kurdish-peshmerga-start-new-round-of-talks-iraqi-state-tv-says-idUSKBN1CY0GF|work=Reuters|date=29 October 2017}} On 31{{nbsp}}October, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi announced that Iraq had regained control of all disputed areas. At a press conference, al-Abadi also accused certain KRG-linked media outlets of "openly inciting violence against federal forces".{{cite news|title=Iraq govt forces in control of all ‘disputed’ areas: PM|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/iraq-govt-forces-in-control-of-all-disputed-areas-pm/952985|work=Anadolu Agency}} Abadi announced that the government planned to start paying the salaries of Peshmerga and civil servants working for KRG, stating, "We will soon be able to pay all the salaries of the Peshmerga and the employees of the region."{{cite news|title=Iraq to pay Kurdish Peshmerga, civil servants, says PM|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-economy/iraq-to-pay-kurdish-peshmerga-civil-servants-says-pm-idUSKBN1D02C5?il=0|work=Reuters}} [[Anadolu News Agency]] meanwhile reported that Turkish and Iraqi forces had moved towards the [[Ibrahim Khalil border crossing]] that morning. The [[Prime Minister of Turkey]] [[Binali Yıldırım]] told members of his [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Justice and Development Party]] in [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|parliament]] that the border gate had been "handed over to the central government". An Iraqi border police captain showed images of the Iraqi flag flying at the crossing, saying that it was "officially under the full control of the Iraqi government." An Iraqi military statement however confirmed that only a delegation led by the chief-of-staff [[Othman al-Ghanmi]] had visited Ibrahim Khalil and Faysh Khabur to determine military and security requirements for taking control.{{cite news|title=Iraq 'to take control of Kurdistan border crossings'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41816138|work=BBC}} Iraqi troops were however deployed at the border crossing with Iraqi positions set up between Turkish and Iraqi Kurdish checkpoints, according to a security source in Baghdad. KRG officials meanwhile stated they had not relinquished control of the crossing, with [[Hoshyar Zebari]] stating that discussions were needed to allow Iraqi oversight at the border.{{cite news|title=Iraqi authorities gain the first foothold at Kurdish frontier with Turkey|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-turkey/iraqi-authorities-gain-first-foothold-at-kurdish-frontier-with-turkey-idUSKBN1D00SQ?il=0|work=Reuters}} On 1{{nbsp}}November, the Iraqi Joint Operations Command accused the Kurdish military of reneging on the draft agreement for the federal military to redeploy federal forces in disputed areas and border crossing points. It also accused them of moving their forces and building new defensive lines during the negotiation period to deter the redeployment of the federal Iraqi forces.{{cite news|title=1st LD: Iraq accuses Kurdish military of reneging on an agreement to redeploy federal forces|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-11/02/c_136721179.htm|work=news.xinhuanet.com}} The JOC threatened to resume military operations to capture Kurdish-held territory.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds/iraq-threatens-to-resume-military-operations-against-kurds-idUSKBN1D15YD?il=0|title=Iraq threatens to resume military operations against Kurds|work=Reuters}} The KRG on 2{{nbsp}}November offered a joint deployment at Faysh Khabur, which its defense department stated was part of a "deconfliction" proposal on 31{{nbsp}}October, including a ceasefire on all fronts, continued cooperation in fight against ISIL and joint deployment in disputed areas.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-turkey/kurds-offer-joint-border-deployment-as-iraq-threatens-to-resume-military-operations-idUSKBN1D20GA|title=Kurds offer joint border deployment as Iraq threatens more military operations|work=Reuters}} The KRG on the same day also accused the central Iraqi government of being "not interested" in joint deployment at the border with Turkey.{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/iraq-not-interested-in-reaching-deal-say-kurds/a-41206881|title=Iraq 'not interested' in reaching deal, say Kurds|work=Deustche-Welle}} [[Prime Minister of Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Nechirvan Barzani]] stated on 6 November that the KRG would hand over the oil revenue in exchange for the central government agreeing to pay the customary 17% share of the federal budget.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurdistan-budget/iraq-cabinet-plans-to-cut-kurdistan-share-in-2018-federal-budget-idUSKBN1D627S|title=Iraq cabinet plans to cut Kurdistan share in 2018 federal budget|work=Reuters}} The [[Federal Supreme Court of Iraq|Supreme Federal Court]] ruled on the same day that no region or province could secede.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds/iraqcourt-rules-no-region-can-secede-after-kurdish-independence-bid-idUSKBN1D617O|title=Iraq court rules no region can secede after Kurdish independence bid|work=Reuters}} KRG stated on 14 November that it will accept the court's ruling.{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20171114-iraq-kurdistan-respect-court-decision-banning-secession-baghdad|title=Iraq's Kurdistan to respect court decision banning secession|work=France24}} Haider al-Abadi stated on 14{{nbsp}}November that he would act soon over border areas under Kurdish control, but predicted Iraqi forces would regain them without violence. "We will regain control on border areas without escalation. But our patience will run out. We will not wait forever. We will take action."{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds/abadi-says-iraq-to-act-soon-over-border-areas-in-stand-off-with-kurds-idUSKBN1DE0XD|title=Abadi says Iraq to act soon over border areas in stand-off with Kurds|work=Reuters}} The Iraqi Supreme Court ruled the referendum as unconstitutional and its results void on 20{{nbsp}}November. Nechirvan Barzani meanwhile blamed the court of reaching the decsion unilaterally without any KRG input and asked for a third party to mediate in negotiations between central government and the KRG.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds/iraqi-court-rules-kurdish-independence-vote-unconstitutional-idUSKBN1DK0Q6|title=Iraqi court rules Kurdish independence vote unconstitutional|work=Reuters}} The central government later listed 13 preconditions for dialogue including, a handwritten note of annulment of the referendum, which the federal court ruled illegal and KRG respected the ruling but didn't formally renounce it. It also asked for guarantee of not seeking independence, handing over all border crossings and airports as well as all future federal revenues.{{cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/baghdad-lists-13-preconditions-for-talks-with-kurds-1.690507|title=Baghdad lists 13 preconditions for talks with Kurds|work=The National}} KRG agreed to the conditions and Abadi announced that talks will be resumed.{{cite news|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1215016/middle-east|title=Kurdish government accepts Baghdad’s conditions to end dispute|work=Arab News}} A [[Council of Representatives of Iraq|MP]] of Abadi's ruling bloc stated on 4 January 2018 that a parliamentary committee would be set up to resolve all disputes. Meanwhile, a delegation of Kurdish parties met Abadi according to a statement by his office.{{cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/iraq-to-set-up-joint-parliamentary-panel-with-kurds-1.692852|title=Iraq to set up joint parliamentary panel with Kurds|work=The National}} Abadi announced on 13 March that the airports of the region will be reopened to international flights, with flights possibly resuming in a week. The statement added that Kurdish authorities had agreed for the two airports in [[Erbil]] and [[Sulaimaniyah]] with international flights to come under federal control. Kurdish authorities confirmed that airports will come under federal control and would report to the [[Ministry of Interior (Iraq)|central Interior Ministry]].{{cite news|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/baghdad-ends-air-blockade-iraqi-kurdistan-2/|title=Baghdad ends air blockade on Iraqi Kurdistan|work=deutsche-Welle}} The federal government announced on 19 March that it had paid salaries to employees in the region for the first time since 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds/iraq-sends-money-to-pay-kurdish-salaries-for-first-time-since-2014-idUSKBN1GV0T1|title=Iraq sends money to pay Kurdish salaries for first time since 2014|work=Reuters}} ==Reactions== ===International=== * {{Flag|Turkey}}: In a statement on 16{{nbsp}}October 2017, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Turkey)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said that it supported Iraq's move to "...restore peace and stability in the country, including Kirkuk...", and warned the KRG that it will be held responsible for allowing PKK to penetrate the city. It added that Turkey was closely monitoring Iraq's steps to "restore its constitutional sovereignty over Kirkuk, a homeland for [[Iraqi Turkmens|Turkmens]] for centuries, after the illegitimate [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|referendum]] conducted by the KRG."{{cite web |url= https://www.dailysabah.com/diplomacy/2017/10/16/turkey-supports-iraqs-moves-to-restore-peace-order-in-kirkuk-mfa-says |title= Turkey supports Iraq's moves to restore peace, order in Kirkuk, MFA says |work= Daily Sabah |date= 16 October 2017 |access-date= 16 October 2017}} [[Deputy Prime Minister of Turkey|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[Bekir Bozdağ]] held KRG President Barzani responsible for regional disputes stating, "Barzani should own up to his mistakes. Only saying ‘I’ve frozen the referendum’ is not enough [...], the cancellation of the referendum is needed."{{cite web |url= http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/turkish-deputy-pm-barzani-should-own-up-to-mistakes/951904 |title=Turkish deputy PM: Barzani should own up to mistakes |work= Anadolu Agency |date= 30 October 2017 |access-date= 2 November 2017}} * {{Flag|United States}}: [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] expressed disappointment that the two sides were fighting while stating that the United States was not taking sides.{{cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-trump/u-s-not-taking-sides-in-iraqi-kurdish-dispute-trump-idUKKBN1CL2P6|title=U.S. 'not taking sides' in Iraqi-Kurdish dispute – Trump|work=Reuters}} The [[United States Department of Defense|Pentagon]] urged Iraqi and Kurdish forces to avoid "additional escalatory actions" after a skirmish over Kirkuk city.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/355671-pentagon-urges-kurds-iraqis-to-avoid-escalating-conflict|title=Pentagon urges Kurds, Iraqis to avoid escalating conflict|work=The Hill}} It described the Iraqi takeover of Kirkuk as a "coordinated movement, not attacks".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/16/iraq-kurdish-forces-army-us-military|title=US military rushes to defuse looming crisis in Kirkuk after Iraqi army advances|work=The Guardian}} The [[United States Department of State|State Department]] urged the Iraqi government to avoid clashes by limiting movement of federal troops to those coordinated with the KRG. It also added, "The reassertion of federal authority over disputed areas in no way changes their status – they remain disputed until their status is resolved in accordance with the Iraqi constitution."{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kirkuk-usa/us-urges-iraq-to-avoid-clashes-with-kurds-near-kirkuk-idUSKBN1CP2R2|title=U.S. urges Iraq to avoid clashes with Kurds near Kirkuk|work=Reuters}} [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Rex Tillerson]] called on both parties to resolve the conflict through dialogue.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-us/tillerson-urges-iraq-kurds-to-resolve-conflict-through-dialogue-idUSKBN1CS2BA|title=Tillerson urges Iraq, Kurds to resolve conflict through dialogue|work=Reuters}} * {{Flag|Iran}}: [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah]] [[Ali Khamenei]] supported Iraqi PM Haider al-Abadi amidst Iraq's clashes with the Kurds. [[Office of the Supreme Leader of Iran]] issued a statement that Khamenei "gave his support for measures taken by the Iraqi government to defend the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Iraq."{{cite news|url=http://nation.com.pk/27-Oct-2017/iraq-pm-wins-iran-support-as-forces-battle-is-kurds|title=Iraq PM wins Iran support as forces battle IS, Kurds|work=Agence-France Presse|publisher=The Nation}} * {{Flag|Germany}}: [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)|Foreign Minister]] [[Sigmar Gabriel]] called on all parties to immediately halt the military actions and engage in direct dialogue. [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)|Defense Minister]] [[Ursula von der Leyen]] announced that Germany will suspend its mission to train Peshmerga because of the conflict.{{cite news|title=Germany suspends training of Kurdish fighters in northern Iraq|first=Riham|last=Alkousaa|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-germany/germany-suspends-training-of-kurdish-fighters-in-northern-iraq-idUSKBN1CN1S9|date=18 October 2017|work=Reuters}} On 20 October, a spokesman for the defense ministry said that the mission will be resumed if the clashes don't worsen.{{cite news|title=Germany says hopes to resume training of Kurdish fighters in Northern Iraq|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-kurds-germany/germany-says-hopes-to-resume-training-of-kurdish-fighters-in-northern-iraq-idUSKBN1CP1HA|date=20 October 2017}} The training mission was restarted later. The Defense Ministry spokesman said on 23 October that Germany will ensure that weapons supplied by it will only be used against ISIL.{{cite news|title=German army restarts training Iraqi Kurds, but future of mission in doubt|work=Deutsche-Welle|url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-army-restarts-training-iraqi-kurds-but-future-of-mission-in-doubt/a-41070521|date=23 October 2017}} * {{Flag|France}}: [[Élysée Palace]] released a statement saying, "The president of the Republic asked for everything possible to be done to avoid conflict between Iraqis and that, within the limits of the unity of Iraq and its constitution, a dialogue taking account of the rights of the Kurds and the minorities should be held between Erbil [the Iraqi Kurdish capital] and Baghdad." [[President of France|President]] [[Emmanuel Macron]] welcomed establishment of a committee to discuss joint deployment of both sides in disputed areas.{{cite news|title=Macron urges Iraq's al-Abadi to hold dialogue with Kurds|url=http://en.rfi.fr/middle-east/20171029-macron-urges-iraqs-al-abadi-hold-dialogue-kurds|work=Radio France Internationale|date=29 October 2017}} * {{Flag|Israel}}: According to Israeli officials, [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] was lobbying world powers to prevent further setbacks to Iraqi Kurds as they lose ground to Baghdad's army. Israel is the only major power that has endorsed statehood for the Kurdish people.{{cite news|title=Netanyahu lobbies world powers to stem Iraqi Kurd setbacks|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-kurds-israel/netanyahu-lobbies-world-powers-to-stem-iraqi-kurd-setbacks-idUSKBN1CP181|work=Reuters|date=2017}} * {{Flag|Canada}}: The [[Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian military]] suspended its support to Iraqi forces and Peshmerga amid the clashes.{{cite news|title=Canada halts military aid to Iraqi and Kurdish forces amid clashes|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3829680/canada-halts-military-aid-iraq-kurdish-forces/|work=Global News}} ===Domestic=== * {{flagicon|Iraqi Kurdistan}} [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]: ** Opposition parties have demanded the dissolution of Barzani's administration.{{cite news|title=Kurdistan Opposition Demands Barzani Administration's Dissolution – Gorran Group|url=https://sputniknews.com/middleeast/201710241058507921-goran-barzani-kurdistan/|work=sputniknews.com|language=en}}{{cite news|title=ثلاثة أحزاب كردية تطالب بحل رئاسة كردستان وتشكيل حكومة مؤقتة|url=https://aawsat.com/home/article/1062761/%D8%AB%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AB%D8%A9-%D8%A3%D8%AD%D8%B2%D8%A7%D8%A8-%D9%83%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%AA%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8-%D8%A8%D8%AD%D9%84-%D8%B1%D8%A6%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9-%D9%83%D8%B1%D8%AF%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%88%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%83%D9%8A%D9%84-%D8%AD%D9%83%D9%88%D9%85%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%A4%D9%82%D8%AA%D8%A9|work=aawsat.com|language=ar}} ** According to [[Nechirvan Barzani]], the rival Talabani political family committed "a great and historic treason against Kurdistan". ** President Barzani on 29{{nbsp}}October blamed the central government in Baghdad for the crisis, while addressing the Kurdistan region in the first televised speech since the independence referendum stating, "They (Baghdad) used the referendum as an excuse. Their bad intentions were very clear from a long time ago."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/iraqi-kurdish-leader-to-devolve-powers-after-thorny-vote/2017/10/29/e38fe6b6-bcb2-11e7-9294-705f80164f6e_story.html|title=Clashes around parliament as Iraqi Kurdish leader steps down|work=Associated Press|publisher=Washington Post}} ** Rival Kurdish factions accused each other of betraying Kirkuk to Iraqi forces. ** KRG [[Vice President]] Kosrat Rasul called the Iraqi forces in Kirkuk and other areas "invaders" ; for this, Iraq's Supreme Court Justice Council ordered his arrest. * {{Flag|Iraq}}: ** In a statement, the Iraqi government accused Kurdish authorities of bringing fighters from Turkey's outlawed [[Kurdistan Workers Party]] (PKK) to the disputed province of Kirkuk, in a move it called a "declaration of war".{{cite news|title=Iraq accuses Kurds of 'declaration of war' in Kirkuk|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/iraq-accuses-kurds-declaration-war-kirkuk-171015162837238.html|work=aljazeera.com}} ** [[Operation Inherent Resolve]] (OIR): In a statement on 16{{nbsp}}October, the coalition announced that Coalition forces and advisors are not supporting Government of Iraq or Kurdistan Regional Government activities near Kirkuk and strongly urged all sides to avoid escalatory actions.{{cite web|url=http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/News-Releases/Article/1343292/coalition-statement-on-military-movements-near-kirkuk/|title=Coalition Statement on Military Movements Near Kirkuk|date=16 October 2017|access-date=16 October 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2017 Iraqi-Kurdish conflict}} [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:2017 in Iraq]] [[Category:2017 in Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Civil wars in Iraq]] [[Category:Kirkuk Governorate]] [[Category:Iraqi–Kurdish conflict]] [[Category:October 2017 events in Iraq]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Wars involving the Peshmerga]] [[Category:2017 in the Iraqi Civil War]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox summit | summit_name = 6th World Festival of Youth and Students | other_titles = | image = [[File:Fmje-6.jpg|300px]] | alt = | caption = | country = {{flag|Soviet Union}}
({{flag|Russian SFSR}}) | date = {{Start date|1957}} | venues = | cities = [[Moscow]] | participants = 34,000, from 130 countries }} The '''6th [[World Festival of Youth and Students]]''' (Russian: Всемирный фестиваль молодёжи и студентов) was opened on 28 July 1957, in [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]]. The festival attracted 34,000 people from 130 countries. This became possible after the bold political changes initiated by [[Nikita Khrushchev]]. It was the first World Festival of Youth and Students held in the Soviet Union, which was opening its doors for the first time to the world.[http://www.russiatoday.ru/features/news/11587 Moscow marks 50 years since youth festival] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215123836/http://www.russiatoday.ru/features/news/11587 |date=2007-12-15 }} The Khrushchev reforms, known as [[Khrushchev's Thaw]], resulted in some changes in the Soviet Union. Foreigners could come for a visit, and people were allowed to meet foreigners, albeit only in groups under supervision. However, that did not stop people from making friends. Russian foreign language students volunteered as interpreters. Music from many world cultures came to USSR with the festival. People were dancing on the streets holding hands with foreigners from all over the world. Jazz musician [[Aleksei Kozlov (musician)|Aleksey Kozlov]] had a chance to play with foreign musicians. The popular ensemble [[Druzhba (band)|Druzhba]] from [[Leningrad]] became the winner of the First Prize{{cite web|title=Pjecha Edita |url=http://www.geocities.com/wlad_11514/polacyen.htm#pjecha |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kjLATXyC?url=http://www.geocities.com/wlad_11514/polacyen.htm |archivedate=2009-10-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }} in popular music, thanks to its lead singer, [[Edita Piekha|Edyta Piecha]], the star of the 1950s who could sing in many languages. [[Edita Piekha|Edyta Piecha]], [[Vladimir Troshin]] and international guests of the festival together performed the popular song ''[[Moscow Nights]]''. The festival's sports programme featured an [[Athletics at the 1957 World Festival of Youth and Students|athletics competition]].[http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/uie.htm World Student Games (UIE)]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2014-12-09. ==References== {{Reflist}} *Moscow marks 50 years since youth festival: [https://web.archive.org/web/20071215123836/http://www.russiatoday.ru/features/news/11587] *PJECHA Edita : {{cite web|title=Names of those persons of a Polish nationality here have come |url=http://www.geocities.com/wlad_11514/polacyen.htm#pjecha |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kjLATXyC?url=http://www.geocities.com/wlad_11514/polacyen.htm |archivedate=2009-10-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }} {{WFYS editions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:World Festival Of Youth And Students}} [[Category:World Festival of Youth and Students]] [[Category:Children's film festivals]] [[Category:History of the Soviet Union and Soviet Russia]] [[Category:1957 in Moscow]] [[Category:Student film festivals]] [[Category:1957 festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1957 in multi-sport events]] [[Category:Multi-sport events in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Sports festivals in Russia]] {{film-festival-stub}}

An '''advanced persistent threat''' ('''APT''') is a stealthy computer network attack in which a person or group gains unauthorized access to a network and remains undetected for an extended period. The term's definition was traditionally associated with nation-state sponsorship, but over the last few years we’ve seen multiple examples of non-nation state groups conducting large-scale targeted intrusions for specific goals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cybereason.com/blog/advanced-persistent-threat-apt|title=What is an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)?|last=Maloney|first=Sarah|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref>
An APT may have either business or political motives. APT processes require a high degree of covertness over a long period of time. The "advanced" process signifies sophisticated techniques using malware to exploit vulnerabilities in systems. The "persistent" process suggests that an external [[command and control (malware)|command and control]] system is continuously monitoring and extracting data from a specific target. The "threat" process indicates [[HUMINT|human involvement]] in [[Active measures|orchestrating]] the attack.<ref name="academia.edu">{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/6309905/Advanced_Persistent_Threat_-_APT |title=Advanced Persistent Threat - APT |author= Dr. Sam Musa}}</ref>
APT usually refers to a group, such as a [[government]], with both the capability and the intent to target, persistently and effectively, a specific entity. The term is commonly used to refer to [[Internet|cyber]] threats, in particular that of [[Internet]]-enabled espionage using a variety of intelligence gathering techniques to access sensitive information,<ref name="Dell SecureWorks">{{cite web|title=Anatomy of an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT)|url=https://www.secureworks.com/resources/sb-advanced-threat-protection-with-dell-secureworks|publisher=Dell SecureWorks|accessdate=2012-05-21}}</ref> but applies equally to other threats such as that of traditional espionage or attacks.<ref name="Command Five Pty Ltd">{{cite web|title=Are you being targeted by an Advanced Persistent Threat?|url=http://www.commandfive.com/apt.html|publisher=Command Five Pty Ltd|accessdate=2011-03-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110406182451/http://www.commandfive.com/apt.html|archive-date=2011-04-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Other recognized attack vectors include infected media, [[Supply chain attack|supply chain compromise]], and human intelligence and deception. The purpose of these attacks is to place custom malicious code on one or multiple computers for specific tasks and to remain undetected for the longest possible period. Knowing the attacker artifacts, such as file names, can help a professional make a network-wide search to gather all affected systems.<ref name="maliciousfilehunter.com">{{cite web|title=Search for malicious files|url=https://www.maliciousfilehunter.com/feature-live-search.php|publisher=Malicious File Hunter|accessdate=2014-10-10}}</ref> Individuals, such as an individual adversary, are not usually referred to as an APT, as they rarely have the resources to be both advanced and persistent even if they are intent on gaining access to, or attacking, a specific target.<ref name="commandfive.com">{{cite web|title=The changing threat environment ...|url=http://www.commandfive.com/threats.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120724104653/http://www.commandfive.com/threats.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-07-24|publisher=Command Five Pty Ltd|accessdate=2011-03-31}}</ref>
==History and targets== Warnings against targeted, socially-engineered emails dropping trojans to exfiltrate sensitive information were published by UK and US [[Computer emergency response team|CERT]] organisations in 2005. This method was used throughout the early 1990's and does not in itself constitute a APT. The term "advanced persistent threat" has been cited as originating from the [[United States Air Force]] in 2006<ref>{{cite web|title=Assessing Outbound Traffic to Uncover Advanced Persistent Threat|url=http://www.sans.edu/student-files/projects/JWP-Binde-McRee-OConnor.pdf|publisher=SANS Technology Institute|accessdate=2013-04-14}}</ref> with Colonel Greg Rattray cited as the individual who coined the term. <ref>{{cite web|title=Introducing Forrester's Cyber Threat Intelligence Research|url=http://blogs.forrester.com/rick_holland/13-02-14-introducing_forresters_cyber_threat_intelligence_research|publisher=Forrester Research|accessdate=2014-04-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415054512/http://blogs.forrester.com/rick_holland/13-02-14-introducing_forresters_cyber_threat_intelligence_research|archive-date=2014-04-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> However, the term APT was used within telecommunications carriers years previously.
The [[Stuxnet]] [[computer worm]], which targeted the computer hardware of [[Iran's nuclear program]], is one example. In this case, the Iranian government might consider the Stuxnet creators to be an advanced persistent threat.
Within the [[computer security]] community, and increasingly within the media, the term is almost always used in reference to a long-term pattern of sophisticated computer network exploitation aimed at governments, companies, and political activists, and by extension, also to attribute attributes to the groups behind these attacks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Advanced Persistent Threats: Learn the ABCs of APTs - Part A|url=https://www.secureworks.com/blog/advanced-persistent-threats-apt-a|website=SecureWorks|publisher=SecureWorks|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> Advanced persistent threat (APT) as a term may be shifting focus to computer based hacking due to the rising number of occurrences. [[PC World]] reported an 81 percent increase from 2010 to 2011 of particularly advanced targeted computer attacks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Olavsrud|first=Thor|title=Targeted Attacks Increased, Became More Diverse in 2011|url=http://www.pcworld.com/printable/article/id,254730/printable.html|publisher=PCWorld}}</ref>
Actors in many nations have used [[cyberspace]] as a means to gather intelligence on individuals and groups of individuals of interest.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Evolving Crisis|url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/08_16/b4080032220668.htm|publisher=BusinessWeek|date=April 10, 2008|accessdate=2010-01-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100110120647/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/08_16/b4080032220668.htm| archivedate= 10 January 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The New E-spionage Threat |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/08_16/b4080032218430.htm |publisher=BusinessWeek |date=April 10, 2008 |accessdate=2011-03-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110418080952/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/08_16/b4080032218430.htm |archivedate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Google Under Attack: The High Cost of Doing Business in China |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,672742,00.html |publisher=Der Spiegel |date=2010-01-19 |accessdate=2010-01-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100121005238/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C672742%2C00.html |archivedate=21 January 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The [[United States Cyber Command]] is tasked with coordinating the US military's offensive and defensive [[Cyber-Attacks|cyber]] operations.
Numerous sources have alleged that some APT groups are affiliated with, or are agents of, [[nation-state]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Under Cyberthreat: Defense Contractors |url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jul2009/tc2009076_873512.htm |publisher=BusinessWeek |date=July 6, 2009 |accessdate=2010-01-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111174243/http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/jul2009/tc2009076_873512.htm |archivedate=11 January 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Understanding the Advanced Persistent Threat|url=http://tominfosec.blogspot.com/2010/02/understanding-apt.html|publisher=Tom Parker|date=February 4, 2010|accessdate=2010-02-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Advanced Persistent Threat (or Informationized Force Operations)|url=http://www.usenix.org/event/lisa09/tech/slides/daly.pdf|publisher=Usenix, Michael K. Daly|date=November 4, 2009|accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref> Businesses holding a large quantity of [[personally identifiable information]] are at high risk of being targeted by advanced persistent threats, including:<ref name="Dell SecureWorks"/>
A Bell Canada study provided deep research in to the anatomy of APTs and uncovered widespread presence in Canadian government and critical infrastructure. Attribution was established to Chinese and Russian actors. <ref>{{cite web|title=APT0 Study on the Analysis of Darknet Space for Predictive Indicators of Cyber Threat Activity|url=http://publications.gc.ca/collections/collection_2016/rddc-drdc/D68-3-007-2013-eng.pdf}}</ref>
*Higher education<ref>{{cite web|last=Ingerman|first=Bret|title=Top-Ten IT Issues, 2011|url=http://www.educause.edu/ero/article/top-ten-it-issues-2011|publisher=Educause Review}}</ref> *Financial institutions
==Characteristics== Bodmer, Kilger, Carpenter and Jones defined the following APT criteria:<ref>{{Cite book |title=[[Reverse Deception: Organized Cyber Threat Counter-Exploitation]] |author=Sean Bodmer |author2=Dr. Max Kilger |author3=Gregory Carpenter |author4=Jade Jones |year=2012 |publisher=McGraw-Hill Osborne Media |isbn=978-0071772495}}</ref>
* Objectives – The end goal of the threat, your adversary * Timeliness – The time spent probing and accessing your system * Resources – The level of knowledge and tools used in the event (skills and methods will weigh on this point) * Risk tolerance – The extent the threat will go to in order to remain undetected * Skills and methods – The tools and techniques used throughout the event * Actions – The precise actions of a threat or numerous threats * Attack origination points – The number of points where the event originated * Numbers involved in the attack – How many internal and external systems were involved in the event, and how many people's systems have different influence/importance weights * Knowledge source – The ability to discern any information regarding any of the specific threats through online information gathering (you might be surprised by what you can find by being a little proactive)
==Life cycle== [[File:Advanced persistent threat lifecycle.jpg|right|Diagram depicting the life cycle staged approach of an advanced persistent threat (APT) which repeats itself once complete.]] Actors behind advanced persistent threats create a growing and changing risk to organizations' financial assets, intellectual property, and reputation<ref>{{cite web|title=Outmaneuvering Advanced and Evasive Malware Threats|url=https://www.secureworks.com/resources/wp-outmaneuvering-advanced-and-evasive-malware-threats|website=Secureworks|publisher=Secureworks Insights|accessdate=24 February 2016}}</ref> by following a continuous process or [[kill chain]]: # Target specific organizations for a singular objective # Attempt to gain a foothold in the environment (common tactics include [[spear phishing]] emails) # Use the compromised systems as access into the target network # Deploy additional tools that help fulfill the attack objective # Cover tracks to maintain access for future initiatives
The global landscape of APTs from all sources is sometimes referred to in the singular as "the" APT, as are references to the actor behind a specific incident or series of incidents, but the definition of APT includes both actor and method.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}
In 2013, Mandiant presented results of their research on alleged Chinese attacks using APT methodology between 2004 and 2013<ref name="mandiant">{{cite web|url=http://intelreport.mandiant.com/ |title=APT1: Exposing One of China's Cyber Espionage Units |year=2013 |publisher=Mandiant}}</ref> that followed similar lifecycle: * '''Initial compromise''' – performed by use of [[Social engineering (security)|social engineering]] and [[spear phishing]], over email, using [[zero-day virus]]es. Another popular infection method was planting [[malware]] on a website that the victim's employees will be likely to visit. * '''Establish Foothold''' – plant [[remote administration software]] in victim's network, create net backdoors and tunnels allowing stealth access to its infrastructure. * '''Escalate privileges''' – use [[exploit (computer security)|exploits]] and [[password cracking]] to acquire administrator privileges over victim's computer and possibly expand it to [[Windows domain]] administrator accounts. * '''Internal reconnaissance''' – collect information on surrounding infrastructure, trust relationships, [[Windows domain]] structure. * '''Move laterally''' – expand control to other workstations, servers and infrastructure elements and perform data harvesting on them. * '''Maintain presence''' – ensure continued control over access channels and credentials acquired in previous steps. * '''Complete mission''' – exfiltrate stolen data from victim's network.
In incidents analysed by Mandiant, the average period over which the attackers controlled the victim's network was one year, with longest – almost five years.<ref name="mandiant" /> The infiltrations were allegedly performed by Shanghai-based [[PLA Unit 61398|Unit 61398]] of [[People's Liberation Army]]. Chinese officials have denied any involvement in these attacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/20/us-china-hacking-idUSBRE91I06120130220 |title=China says U.S. hacking accusations lack technical proof |year=2013 |publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
Previous reports from Secdev had previously discovered and implicated Chinese actors. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nartv.org/mirror/ghostnet.pdf |title=GhostNet” was a large-scale cyber spying operation}}</ref>
==Terminology== Definitions of precisely what an APT is can vary, but can be summarized by their named requirements below:<ref name="Command Five Pty Ltd"/><ref name="commandfive.com"/><ref>{{cite web|title=What's an APT? A Brief Definition|url=https://www.damballa.com/knowledge/advanced-persistent-threats.php|publisher=Damballa|date=January 20, 2010|accessdate=2010-01-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100211122715/http://www.damballa.com/solutions/advanced-persistent-threats.php| archivedate= 11 February 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
* ''Advanced'' – Operators behind the threat have a full spectrum of intelligence-gathering techniques at their disposal. These may include computer intrusion technologies and techniques, but also extend to conventional intelligence-gathering techniques such as telephone-interception technologies and satellite imaging. While individual components of the attack may not be classed as particularly "advanced" (e.g. [[malware]] components generated from commonly available do-it-yourself malware construction kits, or the use of easily procured exploit materials), their operators can typically access and develop more advanced tools as required. They often combine multiple targeting methods, tools, and techniques in order to reach and compromise their target and maintain access to it. Operators may also demonstrate a deliberate focus on operational security that differentiates them from "less advanced" threats. * ''Persistent'' – Operators give priority to a specific task, rather than opportunistically seeking information for financial or other gain. This distinction implies that the attackers are guided by external entities. The targeting is conducted through continuous monitoring and interaction in order to achieve the defined objectives. It does not mean a barrage of constant attacks and malware updates. In fact, a "low-and-slow" approach is usually more successful. If the operator loses access to their target they usually will reattempt access, and most often, successfully. One of the operator's goals is to maintain long-term access to the target, in contrast to threats who only need access to execute a specific task. * ''Threat'' – APTs are a threat because they have both capability and intent. APT attacks are executed by coordinated human actions, rather than by mindless and automated pieces of code. The operators have a specific objective and are skilled, motivated, organized and well funded. Note that actors are not limited to nation states.
==Mitigation strategies== There are hundreds of millions{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} of malware variations, which makes it extremely challenging to protect organizations from APT. While APT activities are stealthy and hard to detect, the command and control network traffic associated with APT can be detected at the network layer level with sophisticated methods. Deep log analyses and log correlation from various sources is of limited usefulness in detecting APT activities. It is challenging to separate noises from legitimate traffic. Traditional security technology and methods have been ineffective in detecting or mitigating APTs. Active cyber defence has yielded greater efficacy in detecting and prosecuting APTs (find, fix, finish) when applying cyber threat intelligence to hunt and adversary pursuit activities.

[[File:Guru Hargobind is released from Gwalior Fort by Jahangir's order.jpg|thumb|Guru Hargobind Ji is released from Gwalior Fort by Jahangir's order]] [[File:Diwali fireworks and lighting celebrations India 2012.jpg|thumb|Festive fireworks at Harmandir Sahib temple on Bandi Chhor Divas]] '''Bandi Chhor Divas''' ("Day of Liberation") (ਬੰਦੀ ਛੋੜ ਦਿਵਸ) is a [[Sikhism|Sikh]] holiday which coincides with the day of [[Diwali]]. Sikhs historically celebrated Diwali along with Hindus, with [[Guru Amar Das]] explicitly listing it along with [[Vaisakhi]] as a festival for Sikhs.<ref name="ColeSambhi1995p135">{{cite book|author1=William Owen Cole|author2=Piara Singh Sambhi|title=The Sikhs: Their Religious Beliefs and Practices|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zIC_MgJ5RMUC&pg=PA135|year= 1995|publisher= Sussex Academic Press|isbn=978-1-898723-13-4|pages=135–136}}, '''Quote:''' "Since the time of Guru Amar Das it has been customary for Sikhs to assemble before their Guru on three of the most important Hindu festival occasions - Vaisakhi, Divali and Maha Shivaratri".</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Kathleen Kuiper|title=The Culture of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c8PJFLeURhsC&pg=PA127 |year=2010|publisher= The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-61530-149-2|page=127}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Eleanor Nesbitt|title=Sikhism: a Very Short Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XebnCwAAQBAJ |year=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-874557-0|pages=28-29, 59}}</ref> In late 20th century, Sikh religious leaders increasingly called Diwali as Bandi Chhor Divas, and the [[Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee]] adopted this name along with the [[Nanakshahi calendar]] in 2003.<ref name=nesbitt122>{{cite book|author=Eleanor Nesbitt|title=Sikhism: a Very Short Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XebnCwAAQBAJ |year=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-874557-0|page=6, 122-123}}</ref>
Unlike the Hindu festival of [[Diwali]] whose significance is based on the texts and scriptures of [[Hinduism]], Bandi Chhor Divas celebrates a Sikh historic event related to the sixth Guru, [[Guru Hargobind]]. According to Sikh history, on this day, Guru Hargobind was released from prison by the Mughal Emperor [[Jahangir]] who freed 52 other Hindu kings with him.<ref>Phyllis G. Jestice, [https://books.google.com/books?id=H5cQH17-HnMC&pg=PA345 Holy People of the World: A Cross-cultural Encyclopedia, Volume 1]</ref><ref name="google1">[https://books.google.com/books?id=BEP0Ty-GuVEC&pg=PA48 Sikhism: A Guide for the Perplexed by Arvind-Pal Singh Mandair]</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Knut A. Jacobsen|author2=Kristina Myrvold|title=Sikhs Across Borders: Transnational Practices of European Sikhs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fU8BAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA26 |year=2012|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic |isbn=978-1-4411-0358-1|pages=26–27, 33 with note 19}}</ref>
The Bandi Chhor Divas is celebrated in a manner similar to Diwali, with the lighting of homes and Gurdwaras, feasts, gift giving and family time. It is an important Sikh celebration along with Vaisakhi, Maghi, Holi with Hola Mohalla and [[Guru Nanak Gurpurab|Gurpurab]].<ref name=nesbitt122/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=DQeKTUXphPMC&pg=PA29 Glimpses of Sikhism By Major Nahar Singh Jawandha]</ref> == Description== {{Sikhism sidebar}}
In addition to ''Nagar keertan'' (a street procession) and an ''Akhand paath'' (a continuous reading of [[Guru Granth Sahib]]), Bandi Shor (Shodh) Divas is celebrated with a fireworks display. The Shri Harmandir Sahib, as well as the whole complex, is festooned with thousands of shimmering lights. The temple organizes continuous ''[[kirtan]]'' singing and special musicians. Sikhs consider this occasion as an important time to visit Gurdwaras and spend time with their families.<ref>{{cite book|author=Nikky-Guninder Kaur Singh|title=Sikhism: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w8yWAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT86 |year=2011|publisher =I.B.Tauris|isbn =978-0-85773-549-2|page=86}}</ref>
== History and significance == Guru Hargobind's father [[Guru Arjan]] was arrested under the orders of the Mughal Emperor [[Jahangir]] and he was asked to convert to Islam.<ref name=ps5/><ref name=lkca>{{cite book | last=Kulathungam | first=Lyman | title= Quest: Christ amidst the quest | publisher=Wipf | year=2012 | isbn=978-1-61097-515-5 | pages=175–177}}</ref> He refused, was tortured and executed in 1606 CE.<ref name=ps5/><ref name=thackston>{{cite book |last=Jahangir, Emperor of Hindustan |date=1999 |title=The Jahangirnama: Memoirs of Jahangir, Emperor of India |translator-last=Thackston |translator-first=Wheeler M. |translator-link=Wheeler Thackston |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=59 |isbn=978-0-19-512718-8}}</ref> This event is remembered as a defining moment in Sikh history and as the martyrdom of Guru Arjan.<ref name=ps5/><ref>Louis E. Fenech, Martyrdom in the Sikh Tradition, Oxford University Press, pp. 118-121</ref> After the execution, Guru Hargobind succeeded his father as the next Guru of Sikhism.<ref name=ps5>Pashaura Singh (2005), [http://www.global.ucsb.edu/punjab/journal_12_1/3_singh.pdf Understanding the Martyrdom of Guru Arjan], Journal of Philosophical Society, 12(1), pages 29-62</ref><ref name= "McLeodp20">{{cite book|title= The A to Z of Sikhism|author= [[W.H. McLeod]]|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=vgixwfeCyDAC|publisher= Scarecrow Press|year= 2009|isbn= 9780810863446|page= 20 (Arjan's Death)|quote="The Mughal rulers of Punjab were evidently concerned with the growth of the Panth, and in 1605 the Emperor Jahangir made an entry in his memoirs, the ''Tuzuk-i-Jahāṅgīrī'', concerning Guru Arjan's support for his rebellious son Khusro. Too many people, he wrote, were being persuaded by his teachings, and if the Guru would not become a Muslim the Panth had to be extinguished. Jahangir believed that Guru Arjan was a Hindu who pretended to be a saint and that he had been thinking of forcing Guru Arjan to convert to Islam or his false trade should be eliminated, for a long time. Mughal authorities seem plain to have been responsible for Arjan's death in custody in Lahore, and this may be accepted as an established fact. Whether the death was by execution, the result of torture, or drowning in the Ravi River remains unresolved. For Sikhs, Arjan is the first martyr Guru."}}</ref><ref name=whm>{{cite book|isbn=978-0231068154|publisher=Columbia University Press|author=WH McLeod|date=1989|title=The Sikhs: History, Religion, and Society|pages=26–51}}</ref>
Guru Hargobind, on 24 June 1606, at age 11, was crowned as the sixth Sikh Guru.<ref>Louis E. Fenech, Martyrdom in the Sikh Tradition, Oxford University Press, pages 118-121</ref><ref name=hssingha>HS Singha (2009), Sikh Studies, Book 7, Hemkunt Press, {{ISBN|978-8170102458}}, pages 18-19</ref> At his succession ceremony, he put on two swords: one indicated his spiritual authority (''piri'') and the other, his temporal authority (''miri'').<ref name=hssyan>HS Syan (2013), Sikh Militancy in the Seventeenth Century, IB Tauris, {{ISBN|978-1780762500}}, pages 48-55</ref> Because of the execution of [[Guru Arjan]] by Mughal Emperor Jahangir, Guru Hargobind from the very start was a dedicated enemy of the Mughal rule. He advised Sikhs to arm and fight.<ref name=mah>{{cite book |title=Muslim Rule In India|author=V. D. Mahajan |year=1970|publisher=S. Chand, New Delhi, p.223|isbn=}}</ref> The death of his father at the hands of Jahangir prompted him to emphasise the military dimension of the Sikh community.<ref name="Phyllis2004">{{cite book|title= Holy People of the World: A Cross-cultural Encyclopedia, Volume 1|author= Phyllis G. Jestice|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=H5cQH17-HnMC&pg=PA345|publisher= [[ABC-CLIO]]|year= 2004|isbn= 9781576073551|pages= 345, 346}}</ref>
Jahangir responded by jailing the 14 year old Guru Hargobind at [[Gwalior Fort]] in 1609, on the pretext that the fine imposed on Guru Arjan had not been paid by the Sikhs and Guru Hargobind.<ref name=mandair48>{{cite book|title= Sikhism: A Guide for the Perplexed|author= Arvind-Pal Singh Mandair|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BEP0Ty-GuVEC&pg=PA48|publisher= [[A & C Black]]|year= 2013|isbn= 9781441117083|page= 48}}</ref> It is not clear as to how much time he spent as a prisoner. The year of his release appears to have been either 1611 or 1612, when Guru Hargobind was about 16 years old.<ref name=mandair48/> Persian records, such as ''Dabistan i Mazahib'' suggest he was kept in jail for twelve years, including over 1617-1619 in Gwalior, after which he and his camp were kept under Muslim army's surveillance by Jahangir.<ref name=eos>{{cite web |url=http://www.learnpunjabi.org/eos/index.aspx |title=HARGOBIND GURU (1595-1644) |author=Fauja Singh |editor= Harbans Singh|isbn= 978-8173802041 |website=Encyclopaedia of Sikhism |publisher=Punjabi University Punjabi |access-date=7 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Sikh Review, Volumes 42-43, Issues 491-497|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=1XPXAAAAMAAJ |year=1994|publisher=Sikh Cultural Centre|pages=15-16}}</ref> According to Sikh tradition, Guru Hargobind was released from the bondage of prison on Diwali. This important event in Sikh history is now termed the ''Bandi Chhor Divas'' festival.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eleanor Nesbitt|title=Sikhism: a Very Short Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XebnCwAAQBAJ |year=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-874557-0|pages=28-29, 59, 120-131}}</ref>
