'''Taste Festivals''' is a company which runs a series of [[food festival]]s around the world. As of 2012, these have taken place in fifteen cities. The events typically have the prefix "Taste of", although the company joined forces with [[celebrity chef]] [[Jamie Oliver]] to organise The Big Feastival for the first time in 2011. The events are typically attended by restaurants who operate mini-kitchens, these include [[Michelin star]]red restaurants.
==Description== The events run by Taste Festivals feature mini-kitchens from different restaurants, along with live demonstrations from chefs. The events have their own currency called "crowns" which are used to purchase food from the restaurant's kitchens.<ref name=loves>{{cite news|title=Caterer loves... Taste of London|url=http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/15/06/2006/307205/Caterer-loves.-Taste-of-London.htm|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|date=15 June 2008}}</ref> The restaurants featured have included [[Michelin star]]red establishments such as [[Rhodes 24]] and [[Le Gavroche]] at Taste of London.<ref>{{cite news|title=Taste sensation for chefs and foodies|url=http://news.caterer.com/article/view/restaurant/18651769/taste-sensation-for-chefs-and-foodies/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Caterer.com|date=23 June 2008}}</ref> The Best in Taste award is given out by each festival to the restaurant who serves the best dish at each event.<ref>{{cite news|title=Club Gascon's 'Marmite Royal' Awarded Best Dish at Taste of London|url=http://www.tastefestivals.com/london/news/121/Club-Gascon%E2%80%99s-%E2%80%98Marmite-Royale%E2%80%99-Awarded-Best-Dish-at-Taste|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=''Taste Festivals''|date=23 June 2012}}</ref>
==History== Taste Festivals launched in 2004 with the first Taste of London, which took place at [[Somerset House]].<ref name=esquire>{{cite news|title=The To Do List: Taste of London|url=http://www.esquire.co.uk/2012/06/the-festival-taste-of-london/|date=21 June 2012|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Esquire}}</ref> The London event was moved to [[Regent's Park]] in 2005, where it has remained since.<ref>{{cite news|title=AVA strawberries target top-end market|url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/Business-Support/AVA-strawberries-target-top-end-market|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Morning Advertiser|date=7 July 2005}}</ref><ref name=bestshow2012>{{cite news|last=Ford|first=Richard|title=Best show gong for Taste of London|url=http://www.thegrocer.co.uk/people/best-show-gong-for-taste-of-london/227997.article|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=The Grocer|date=5 April 2012}}</ref> The show was named Best Consumer Show at the 2012 Exhibition News Awards.<ref name=bestshow2012/> A second London based event runs later in the year, entitled Taste of Christmas. It runs on similar principles to the main Taste of London event, although it is instead hosted at the [[ExCeL Centre]].As of 2016, Taste of Christmas is held at Tobacco Docks, London.<ref name=christmas>{{cite news|last=Vines|first=Richard|title=London Chefs Set for Christmas -- With Chocolate: Richard Vines|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aDq4zB_eaUqc|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=16 September 2009}}</ref>
Taste of Edinburgh was first run in 2007, initially at [[The Meadows (park)|The Meadows]], but after two years moved to [[Inverleith Park]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Taste of Edinburgh food festival forced to find a new home|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/taste-of-edinburgh-food-festival-forced-to-find-a-new-home-1-756235|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Scotsman|date=29 September 2009}}</ref> In 2012, the festival was called off at late notice following high levels of rainfall in the days prior to the event making the site unsafe for the expected number of visitors.<ref name=calledoff>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Jim|title=Taste of Edinburgh festival called off after flooded site deemed unsafe|url=http://local.stv.tv/edinburgh/109818-taste-of-edinburgh-festival-called-off-after-flooded-site-deemed-unsafe/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=STV|date=7 July 2012}}</ref> Initially the plans were to continue with the event despite the weather.<ref>{{cite news|last=Piper|first=Laura|title=Brolly up and wellies on for a Taste-tastic time|url=http://local.stv.tv/edinburgh/going-out/articles/109545-taste-tastic-line-up-promises-foodie-fun-with-extra-flavour/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=STV|date=5 July 2012}}</ref> As of 2012, there have been Taste festivals held in fifteen cities around the world, the exhibitors at the 2012 Taste of London held a combined 11 Michelin stars.<ref name=esquire />
The events were expanded to Africa in 2006 with Taste of Joburg,<ref name=joburg>{{cite news|last=Mkwanazi|first=Sibusiso|title=Tasting Joburg|url=http://www.citizen.co.za/citizen/content/en/citizen/lifestyle-features?oid=226067&sn=Detail&pid=146826&Tasting-Joburg|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=The Citizen|date=19 September 2011}}</ref> and expanded in 2008 to add a second South African event with Taste of Cape Town,<ref name=cape>{{cite news|title=Taste of Cape Town|url=http://food.iafrica.com/news/food_news/2303841.htm|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=iafrica.com|date=16 March 2010}}</ref>
In 2013, the Taste festivals were acquired by [[IMG (company)|IMG]].<ref>[http://img.com/news/news/2013/february/img-acquires-taste-festivals-from-brand-events.aspx IMG ACQUIRES TASTE FESTIVALS FROM BRAND EVENTS]</ref>
===The Big Feastival=== Taste Festivals began running the [[Jamie Oliver]] backed Big Feastival in 2011, a combination event featuring both restaurants and musical artists.<ref>{{cite news|last=Luker|first=Sara|title=Food festival featuring Jamie Oliver and Alex James hires House PR|url=http://www.prweek.com/uk/news/1139207/food-festival-featuring-jamie-oliver-alex-james-hires-house-pr/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=PR Week|date=3 July 2012}}</ref> The initial plan was to host the event in [[Victoria Park, London|Victoria Park]] during 2012 to coincide with the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], however due to branding restrictions this plan was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ridley|first=Louise|title=Exclusive: Jamie Oliver Olympic Feastival plans scrapped|url=http://www.eventmagazine.co.uk/news/1128967/Exclusive-Jamie-Oliver-Olympic-Feastival-plans-scrapped/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Event|date=26 April 2012}}</ref> The event instead was arranged to take place at the farm of musician [[Alex James (musician)|Alex James]] in Oxfordshire, who had previously hosted a similar festival in 2011 which resulted in the event's organisers going out of business due to the losses involved.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alex James and Jamie Oliver to host music and food festival|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-berkshire-17728055|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=16 April 2012}}</ref>
==List of Taste Festivals== ;Australia * Taste of Sydney<ref>{{cite news|last=Shailer|first=Annette|title=Food Lovers To Enjoy Taste of Sydney|url=http://www.theshout.com.au/2010/02/19/article/Food-Lovers-To-Enjoy-Taste-of-Sydney/QQYJUWKAZJ|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=The Shout|date=19 February 2010}}</ref> * [http://www.tasteofmelbourne.com.au/ Taste of Melbourne] * [http://www.tasteofperth.com.au/ Taste of Perth]

* Taste of Auckland<ref>{{cite news|title=Taste of Auckland takes Centre Stage for 2010|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK0912/S00207.htm|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Scoop Independent News|date=14 December 2009}}</ref> * Taste of Milan<ref>{{cite news|last=Franchi|first=Luigi|title=Taste of Milano 2012|url=http://www.cateringnews.it/eventi-enogastronomici/taste-milano-2012/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=Catering News|language=Italian}}</ref> *Taste of Hong Kong

revision.text:
{{Infobox newspaper |name = Tell Magazine |logo = Tell Magazine logo.png |logo_size = 200px |type = |format = |foundation = 15 April 1991 |ceased publication = |price = |owners = |publisher = TELL Communications Ltd. |editor = [[Ayodele Akinkuotu (journalist)|Ayodele Akinkuotu]] |language = |circulation = |headquarters = [[Berger, Lagos|Berger]], [[Lagos]] |website = http://www.tell.ng/ }} '''''Tell Magazine''''' is a weekly magazine published in [[Nigeria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tellng.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=72&Itemid=128&limitstart=1|title=About Us - The Company|work=Tell Magazine|accessdate=2011-05-15}}</ref> In 2007, [[BBC News]] described it as "one of Nigeria's most respected business magazines".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6445125.stm|title=Firms struggle in crumbling Nigeria |author= |date=19 March 2007 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref>
==Foundation== ''Tell'' magazine published its first edition on 15 April 1991. All five of the founding editors had worked at ''[[Newswatch (Nigeria)|Newswatch]]'', where they learned to create in-depth, investigative feature stories. They left that magazine due to low pay and disagreements with senior management, hoping that the new magazine would be more fulfilling. Although the magazine's founders had high ambitions, they were not initially hostile to the government. However, they were determined to be free of government or political influence.<ref name=Olukotun2004/>
==Babangida era== The magazine questioned whether General [[Ibrahim Babangida]] was sincere in saying he would hand over to a civilian government. The 2 May 1993 edition with headline "Transition: 21 Traps against handover" was seized, and had to be reprinted in tabloid format. Two more major seizures occurred before Babangida was forced from power in August 1993.<ref name=Olukotun2004/> In all, 500,000 copies were seized in the last four months of Babangida's rule.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aMM2qKU9bVUC&pg=PA66 |page=66 |title=Press freedom and communication in Africa |author=Festus Eribo |publisher=Africa World Press |year=1997|ISBN=0-86543-551-0}}</ref> Tell's circulation rose to as many as 100,000 copies each week in the build-up to the June 1993 presidential election and in the subsequent confusion. Facing harassment from security forces, the magazine began printing underground in July 1993. On 15 August 1993 police raided the offices and arrested editor-in-chief [[Nosa Igiebor (journalist)|Nosa Igiebor]] and editors Kola Ilori, Onome Osifo-Whiskey and Ayodele Akinkuoto. holding them for 12 days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cd.sc.ehu.es/FileRoom/documents/Cases/313tell.html |title=To Tell the Truth Is Risky Business in Nigeria |work=Africa Report |date=Jan–Feb 1994 |accessdate=2011-05-15}}</ref>
==Abacha era== Conditions became more difficult after General [[Sani Abacha]] took power in November 1993. On 2 January 1994 armed policemen and security officers seized 50,000 copies of the magazine at the printer's premises. The issue was titled "The Return of Tyranny - Abacha bares his fangs".<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nbM3JzkVBGQC&pg=PA720 |page=720 |title=Documents of the African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights, Volume 1 |author=African Commission on Human and Peoples' Rights |publisher=Hart Publishing |year=2001 |ISBN=1-84113-092-3}}</ref> The editors resorted to guerrilla tactics to survive, forming cells and frequently moving, with the magazine printed covertly in different locations. They relied on help from civilians, who supported the magazine by providing office space, buying copies and helping in many other ways.<ref name=Olukotun2004/>
After the newspaper published a story that revealed that Abacha was suffering from cirrhosis of the liver, police and military raided Igiebor's house while he was away. His wife was maltreated when she said she did not know where he was. A soldier pointed a gun at his four-year-old daughter, threatening to shoot if Igiebor was not produced.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EKKuU_7NwNkC&pg=PT14 |page=23 |title=Nigeria: the case for peaceful and friendly dissolution |author=Adedapo Adeniran |publisher=The Futility of the Land Use |year=2002 |ISBN=978-34858-7-3}}</ref> Igiebor was jailed for six months from late 1995 to 1996, and later fled abroad to escape the threat of assassination. Osifo-Whiskey also spent six months in detention, arrested after a year in which he avoided his own house and stayed with friends, one of whom was killed.<ref name=Olukotun2004/>
==Awards and recognition== In 1993, the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] presented Igiebor its [[CPJ International Press Freedom Awards|International Press Freedom Award]], "an annual recognition of courageous journalism",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cpj.org/awards/ |title=CPJ International Press Freedom Awards 2011 |year=2011 |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> for his work with the magazine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpj.org/attacks96/frontmatter/ipfa.html |title=Journalists Receive 1996 Press Freedom Awards |year=1996 |publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]] |accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> In 1998, Nosa Igiebor and the staff as a whole were awarded the [[Special Award for Human Rights Journalism Under Threat]] at the [[Amnesty International UK Media Awards]].<ref name="1998 Amnesty Media Awards 001">{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/news/awards/1998.html |title=Amnesty International UK (AIUK) Media Awards 1998 |accessdate=2017-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010513170831/http://www.amnesty.org.uk/news/awards/1998.html |archivedate=May 13, 2001 |df= }}</ref> The award's notice stated; "Tell has continued to publish throughout the period of Nigerian dictatorship despite intimidation, harassment and the detention without charge or trial of Mr Igiebor and other senior members of the Tell staff."<ref name="1998 Amnesty Media Awards 002">{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/news/awards/1998.html |title=Amnesty International UK (AIUK) Media Awards 1998 - Winners - Short-list - Judges |accessdate=2017-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DkDDNDx9?url=http://web.archive.org/web/20010513170831/http://www.amnesty.org.uk/news/awards/1998.html |archivedate=January 17, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|33em|refs= <ref name=Olukotun2004>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qz9BlWO7ExwC&pg=PA79 |page=79ff |chapter=Tell Magazine |title=Repressive state and resurgent media under Nigeria's military dictatorship, 1988-98 |author=Ayo Olukotun |publisher=Nordic Africa Institute |year=2004 |ISBN=91-7106-524-5}}</ref>}} {{Major Nigerian newspapers}}

{{About|a military-related term|the band|Thousand Yard Stare (band)|the Chicane album|Thousand Mile Stare}} [[File:Tom Lea - 2000 Yard Stare.jpg|thumb|upright|[[War artist]] [[Thomas C. Lea, III|Thomas Lea's]] ''The 2000 Yard Stare'']] [[File:WW2 Marine after Eniwetok assault.jpg|thumb|upright|An exhausted [[U.S. Marine]] exhibits the thousand-yard stare after two days of constant fighting at the [[Battle of Eniwetok]], February 1944.]]
The '''thousand-yard stare''' or '''two-thousand-yard stare''' is a phrase often used to describe the blank, unfocused gaze of [[soldier]]s who have become emotionally [[dissociation (psychology)|detached]] from the horrors around them. It is also sometimes used more generally to describe the look of dissociation among victims of other types of trauma.
==Origin== The phrase was popularized after [[Life (magazine)|''Life'' magazine]] published the painting ''Marines Call It That 2,000 Yard Stare'' by [[World War II]] artist and correspondent [[Thomas C. Lea, III|Tom Lea]],<ref>''Life'' magazine, 6/11/1945, p. 65. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_EkEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA61&dq=%22tom%20lea%22&as_pt=MAGAZINES&pg=PA65#v=onepage&q=%22tom%20lea%22&f=false link]</ref> although the painting was not referred to with that title in the 1945 magazine article. The painting, a 1944 portrait of a nameless [[US Marine Corps|Marine]] at the [[Battle of Peleliu]], is now held by the [[United States Army Center of Military History]] in [[Fort Lesley J. McNair]], Washington, D.C.<ref>Jones, James, and Tom Lea (illustration), (1975). - [http://www.milhist.net/global/2000yard.html "Two-Thousand-Yard Stare"]. - ''WW II''. - (c/o Military History Network). - Grosset and Dunlap. - pp.113,116. - {{ISBN|0-448-11896-3}}</ref> About the real-life Marine who was his subject, Lea said:
{{quote|He left the States 31 months ago. He was wounded in his first campaign. He has had [[tropical disease]]s. He half-sleeps at night and gouges [[Jap]]s out of holes all day. Two-thirds of his company has been killed or wounded. He will return to attack this morning. How much can a human being endure?<ref name=ADM438>{{cite web |author = Host: Rear Admiral Gene LaRocque (USN, Ret.); Interviewer & narrator: Sanford Gottlieb; Producers: Matthew Hansen, Nick Moore, Lori McRea, Daniel Sagalyn |title = War through the eyes of artists |work = America's Defense Monitor, Program Number 438 |publisher = Center for Defense Information |year = 1991 |url = http://www.cdi.org/adm/Transcripts/438/ |format = Transcript of televised broadcast |accessdate = 2006-10-27 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061026072828/http://www.cdi.org/adm/Transcripts/438/ |archivedate = 2006-10-26 |df = }}</ref>}}
When recounting his arrival in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam in 1965]], then-Corporal Joe Houle (director of the Marine Corps Museum of the Carolinas in 2002) said he saw no emotion in the eyes of his new squad: "The look in their eyes was like the life was sucked out of them," later learning that the term for their condition was ''the 1,000-yard stare''. "After I lost my first friend, I felt it was best to be detached," he explained.<ref name=Houle>{{cite news |title=Retired Sgt. Maj. Joe Houle recounts Vietnam tour |publisher=Marine Corps News |date=2002-05-02 |first=Sgt. Arthur L. |last=Stone |url=http://www.lejeune.marines.mil/News/tabid/1099/Article/511426/retired-sgt-maj-joe-houle-recounts-vietnam-tour.aspx}}</ref>

'''VegfestAU''' is an [[vegan food|vegan]] [[food festival]] held in [[Sydney]] and [[Melbourne]].
==Sydney== Specifically, on 25 October, the [http://www.crueltyfreefestival.org.au Cruelty Free Festival] will be held in Sydney.

{{World-Scrabble-Championship | year=2015 | date-from=4 November 2015| date-to=8 November 2015| location=Perth, Australia | winner=[[Wellington Jighere]] | number-of-players=131 | sponsor=WESPA | previous=2014|next=2016}} The '''WESPA World Scrabble Championship 2015''' (also known as WESPA Championship or WESPAC) was organised by [[WESPA]], the World English-language Scrabble Players' Association, which commissioned ASPA, the Australian Scrabble Players Association, to hold a World Scrabble Championship invitational event in [[Perth]], [[Western Australia]] from November 4 to 8. [[Mattel]] and Mind Sports International agreed to this.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scrabble.org.au/events/15WSC/index.html|title=WESPA Championship 2015|author=|date=|work=scrabble.org.au|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Results== The winner was Wellington Jighere of [[Nigeria]] who defeated Lewis Mackay of [[England]] by four games to nil in the best-of-seven finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/nov/09/nigerias-wellington-jighere-almost-lost-for-words-after-scrabble-world-title-triumph|title=Nigeria's Wellington Jighere almost lost for words after Scrabble world title triumph|author=Calla Wahlquist|date=|work=the Guardian|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
There were 131 qualifiers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scrabble.org.au/events/15WSC/inv_info.html|title=2015 WESPA SCRABBLE CHAMPIONSHIP|author=|date=|work=scrabble.org.au|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> and it was the first time that the World Championships was won by a player from [[Africa]].
In the first game, Wellington had bingos [[wikt:tindal|TINDALs]], [[wikt:fahlore|FAHLORES]] and [[wikt:viciate|VICIaTES]] while Lewis had TITTERED and OBEISANT, while missing bingo AUTO(G)ENY and a high scoring NIQAB later. Wellington won 529 - 398.
In the second game, Wellington had bingos [[wikt:asthore|AsTHORE]], [[wikt:bling|BLINGIER]] and [[wikt:oersted|OERSTEDS]] while Lewis had [[wikt:controle|COnTROLE]] and a few 35+ plays. Wellington won 438 - 410.
In the third game, Wellington had bingos [[wikt:quoiter|QUOITERS]], MATTERED, MENTORED and [[wikt:adagial|ADAGIAL]] while Lewis had BELAYING and a 61-point CODA. Wellington won 563 - 459.
In the fourth game, Wellington had bingos CREASED and GAINLIER and a 93-point QUIZ while Lewis had [[wikt:avouch|AVOUCHED]] and [[wikt:ironist|IRONISTS]] and a 66-point [[wikt:jomo|JOMO]]. Wellington finished with a 36-point [[wikt:felty|FELTY]] to win the game 449 - 432 and take the title of World Champion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scrabble.org.au/events/15WSC/results.html|title=Play through games|author=|date=|work=scrabble.org.au|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
